Tesla missed its delivery numbers. How important is this?

For the first time since its inception, Tesla delivered less vehicles than the year before. And while it is certainly notable, it is also important to consider that Tesla doesn't trade like a car company and certainly isn't valued as one. 

My take: The miss by about 10k from the whisper number and 20k to achieve Y/Y growth may lead to a short downward pressure after Tesla's remarkable run in Q4, but it doesn't change the thesis of the company and what its investors are in it for. 

1. Autonomy and FSD
2. AI, Robotics and Humanoid Robotics 
3. Energy Capture and innovation 

Trading at around 5x higher (forward PE) than its Mag 7 cohort and 8-12x higher than its automotive peers. Tesla is a car company that isn't a car company. And this will likely lead to bigger swings with exponentially more upside. 

If you want safer exposure to AI or Tech then I see the likes of Google, NVIDIA, Microsoft, Meta, Amazon, and Apple as a safer play. But I don't think Tesla investors are in it for safe. They are in it for the big wins. Always have been. So, today's number means a little, but not much. 

The real question is whether Elon can achieve the vision of autonomy, and humanoid robots? Its investors clearly believe it can. And I tend to not bet against Musk. Maybe his timelines, but not the ultimate outcome.

Trade Recap Of The Day: $QQQ 517c 01/03 @.64 for a gain of 143% 

Why did I take this trade?

- First of all, my bias from the open was bullish as $NVDA was absolutely rocketing right at open. $TSLA also saw some nice strength, as some other large caps did too. 

- My second, and main reasoning for entering the trade was the beautiful bounce from the premarket low ($513.54). As you can see on the chart below, right before my entry, there was a huge red candle which test below this level and bounced right back up. 

- After that red candle formed, I waited for the retest and bounce to confirm my upside bias, and when we retested (see the candle on my entry in the chart below), I entered the play.

- My main target was the $516.60 level, as this was a major level we kept rejecting since yesterday (also see the circles on my chart below).

This was a brief explanation of why I entered this trade!

U.S. Chamber, oil industry sue Vermont over law requiring companies to pay for climate change damage | Lisa Rathke & Michael Casey, CTV News

The U.S. Chamber of Commerce and a top oil and gas industry trade group are suing Vermont over its new law requiring that fossil fuel companies pay a share of the damage caused over several decades by climate change.

The federal lawsuit filed Monday asks a state court to prevent Vermont from enforcing the law, which was passed last year. Vermont became the first state in the country to enact the law after it suffered catastrophic summer flooding and damage from other extreme weather. The state is working to estimate the cost of climate change dating back to Jan. 1, 1995.

The lawsuit argues the U.S. Constitution precludes the act and that the state law is preempted by the federal Clean Air Act. It also argues that the law violates domestic and foreign commerce clauses by discriminating â€œagainst the important interest of other states by targeting large energy companies located outside of Vermont.â€

The Chamber and the other plaintiff in the lawsuit, the American Petroleum Institute, argue that the federal government is already addressing climate change. And because greenhouse gases come from billions of individual sources, they argue it is impossible to measure â€œaccurately and fairlyâ€ the impact of emissions from a particular entity in a particular location over decades.

â€œVermont wants to impose massive retroactive penalties going back 30 years for lawful, out-of-state conduct that was regulated by Congress under the Clean Air Act," said Tara Morrissey, senior vice president and deputy chief counsel of the Chamberâ€™s litigation center. â€œThat is unlawful and violates the structure of the U.S. Constitution â€” one state canâ€™t try to regulate a global issue best left to the federal government. Vermontâ€™s penalties will ultimately raise costs for consumers in Vermont and across the country.â€

A spokesman for the state's Agency of Natural Resources said it had not been formally served with this lawsuit.

Anthony Iarrapino, a Vermont-based lobbyist with the Conservation Law Foundation, said the lawsuit was the fossil fuel industry's way of â€œtrying to avoid accountability for the damage their products have caused in Vermont and beyond.â€

â€œMore states are following Vermontâ€™s lead holding Big Oil accountable for the disaster recovery and cleanup costs from severe storms fueled by climate change, ensuring that families and businesses no longer have to foot the entire bill time and time again," Iarrapino added.

Iraq Surpasses Saudi Arabia in Weekly Oil Exports to US

The US Energy Information Administration (EIA) announced on Saturday that Iraq was the second-largest oil exporter to the United States during the past week, surpassing Saudi Arabia.
The EIA mentioned that the average US imports of crude oil during the past week from nine major countries reached approximately 5.76 million barrels per day, representing a decline of 79,000 barrels per day compared to the previous week, when US oil imports reached 5.84 million barrels per day, Shafaq News reported.

Iraqâ€™s oil exports to the United States reached 212,000 barrels per day last week, representing a decline of 17,000 barrels per day compared to the previous week, when Iraq exported 229,000 barrels per day to the US.

The EIA indicated that most of the United States imports of crude oil during the past week came from Canada at an average of 3.73 million barrels per day, followed by Mexico with an average of 551,000 barrels per day and Venezuela with an average of 353,000 barrels per day.

The United States imported an average of 289,000 barrels per day from Colombia, 280,000 barrels per day from Brazil, 189,000 barrels per day from Libya, 87,000 barrels per day from Saudi Arabia, and 71,000 barrels per day from Nigeria.

In 2024, China made a dramatic shift in its energy strategy by significantly reducing its imports of U.S. crude oil, dropping by nearly 46% compared to the previous year. This change reshapes global energy dynamics, as China, which had been the second-largest importer of U.S. crude, now falls to the sixth position in the global rankings. 

With imports down to 81.9 million barrels in 2024 from 115.6 million barrels in 2023, this move signals a broader transformation in Chinaâ€™s approach to energy procurement. This reduction in U.S. crude imports is part of a larger trend in Chinaâ€™s energy landscape, where the countryâ€™s overall crude imports have also decreased by 7.2%. Factors like intermittent COVID-19 lockdowns, high domestic inventories, and refinery maintenance have contributed to this downturn. 

However, Chinaâ€™s energy strategy is evolving, with the country increasingly turning to alternative suppliers, particularly from politically isolated nations like Russia, Iran, and Venezuela. These countries offer China discounted crude, allowing refiners to secure lower-cost energy while diversifying supply sources and strengthening energy security. 

Chinaâ€™s imports from Russia, Iran, and Venezuela have increased significantly, making up a larger portion of Chinaâ€™s crude oil supply. This shift is driven by economic benefits, as these nations offer cheaper oil due to Western sanctions. In turn, Chinaâ€™s engagement with these countries enhances its geopolitical leverage and reduces its dependence on U.S. energy exports, providing a strategic advantage in the ongoing trade tensions between the U.S. and China. 

This pivot in Chinaâ€™s oil import strategy not only reshapes its energy security but also has far-reaching consequences for the global oil market. It challenges the effectiveness of Western sanctions and exposes vulnerabilities in global energy supply chains, potentially influencing global oil pricing and production strategies. As China strengthens ties with non-Western suppliers, such as Russia and Iran, it positions itself as a central player in the future of global energy markets, with far-reaching implications for U.S.-led frameworks

This guidance, by disqualifying imports of used cooking oil, highlights that our members voices will always be the most effective way to make meaningful change. We will continue to monitor the process and ensure the priority is American farmers and American energy independence.

We believe that it is unlikely (<25% chance) that President Trump will place tariffs on Canadian oil. How can he do so (60% of US imports) while also committing to "maximum pressure" on Iran (1.7MM Bbl/d) and enforcing new sanctions on Russia (0.75-1.5MM Bbl/d) and Venezuela (~0.1MM Bbl/d and an alternative to CDN heavy oil). Further, PADD 2 imports ~3MM Bbl/d from Canada via pipeline with limited/no alternatives. Tariffs also assumed direct pass through to US consumer = inflationary when US 10 year treasuries at 4.6%. 

I met with the CEOs of most CDN oil companies earlier this week and no strong views other than would be temporary and "this too shall pass." 

Canadian energy names have lagged their US peers by ~8% since Premier Smith's comments spooked the market. With WTI spot at $78 and 2025 strip at $73 some names are trading at 17%-19% free cashflow yields at $75. A full tariff (and likely VERY temporary) would lower this to still over 10%. While knee jerk reactions are always possible/likely, given the lag in CDN names to the recent rise in WTI fundamentally valuations in several names are already discounting a full tariff. 

We are seeing tariff angst amongst clients and trading desks report heavy US HF selling/shorting. Uncertainty creates opportunity and while no one can be truly certain on the outcome, to us this has become an alpha generating opportunity, with clarity in the coming weeks.

- Weather volatility took NYMEX through $4 in the front and the CAL25/26 Calendar to $3.90/$4.00. Freeze offs and high demand in January may draw 1 Tcf of gas in January (~0.95 Tcf current consensus)
- Tariffs created a wide performance divergence between Canadian and American gas stocks; TD/ATB see CF impact for gas stocks small to potentially positive

- Enverus found 20% productivity degredation in the Haynesville Shelby Trough (downspacing main culperate); Haynesville as a whole continues to slip Y/Y Bcf/Ft

Should Alberta halt oil exports to the United States? Albertans weigh in

The oil and gas industry is back in the political spotlight, with Alberta Premier Danielle Smith clashing with Trudeau and her fellow premiers over energy policies and economic priorities.

The height of the controversy began earlier this week when the federal government brought the idea of cutting off energy supply to the U.S. and imposing export tariffs on Alberta energy and other products to the United States. Alberta Premier Danielle Smith responded to these threats by saying it would spark a â€œnational unity crisisâ€. She then flipped off the Trudeau Liberalsâ€™ stance, declaring that Alberta would not comply with export tariffs on its oil, gas, and other resources, nor support an outright export ban.

This stems from the statements made by the incoming President of the United States, Donald Trump, who has threatened to impose a 25% export tariff on Canadian goods, citing concerns over border security. He argued that failure to enforce stricter border policies warrants consequences for Canada.

Canadaâ€™s premiers and outgoing Prime Minister Justin Trudeau met to discuss the challenges and explore possible solutions. However, the Alberta premier strongly opposed the proposals put forward. Smith claimed the policies would strangle Albertaâ€™s economy and accused Ottawa of ignoring provincial rights to control their natural resources.

Instead, she urged Canadians to use this tariff threat as an â€œopportunity to correctâ€ the misguided direction of this country.â€ She plans to meet with U.S. lawmakers and officials to make a case against the imposition of tariffs on Canada.

Rebel News took to the streets of downtown Calgary to speak to Albertans about their thoughts on the tariff war between the United States and Canada.

WHAT NIGERIA STANDS TO GAIN FROM BRICS

Nigeria was recently admitted as a â€œpartner countryâ€ of the BRICS bloc of developing economies, according to Brazil, the groupâ€™s chair.

Economically, Nigeria can benefit from increased trade with BRICS nations, especially in oil, gas, agriculture, and manufacturing, which may reduce its dependence on Western economies. Investment from BRICS countries could lead to infrastructure growth and job creation. Being part of BRICS may also help Nigeria reduce reliance on the US dollar for trade, potentially using local currencies or a new BRICS currency.

Politically, Nigeria gains a stronger global voice, potentially influencing international policies and representing African interests. The partnership opens doors to strategic alliances with influential emerging economies. Developmentally, Nigeria could benefit from technological transfers in fields like renewable energy, digital infrastructure, and space technology.

Although Nigeria has been admitted as a partner country, its participation in decision-making will be limited, lacking full membership privileges like voting rights. Nonetheless, Nigeria's inclusion in BRICS signals its rising status in global politics and economics.

The end of an era: How Europe is adapting to the halt of Russian gas via Ukraine

As predicted by Kpler Insight, #gas flows from Slovakia to Austria and Czechia ceased on January 1st. Both countries have increased imports from Germany, primarily benefiting from the lifting of the cross-border gas storage levy, with flows routed through the Brandov and Oberkappel VIPs.

Poland has also halted gas imports via interconnections with Ukraine and Czechia, confirming it had been indirectly sourcing Russian gas through Ukraine until the stoppage. Underground gas storage withdrawals in Slovakia, Austria, and Poland have risen as market players adapt to the evolving supply dynamics.

#LNG will remain central to replacing Russian volumes by 2025, with import capacity in Germany, the Netherlands, Poland, Croatia, Greece, and Italy serving as a critical backbone. However, infrastructure bottlenecks along key gas corridors will likely constrain short-term diversification strategies in the CEE region.

Key factors to watch include negotiations to end the Russia-Ukraine war, delays in LNG projects, sanctions on Russian LNG, higher cross-border tariffs, and flow congestionâ€”each shaping Europe's gas supply dynamics.

The CCMBC, founded in 2016, advocates for policies that support manufacturing, business retention, and job growth across Canada. The Iraqi Parliament has once again postponed the approval of a crucial budget amendment related to the oil exports of the Kurdistan Region. The amendment, which has sparked heated debate, centers around the payment terms for oil production and transportation in the Kurdish-controlled areas.

In a move that has further intensified the ongoing dispute, Iraqi Prime Minister Mohammed Shia' Al Sudani has proposed a new clause demanding that the Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG) hand over its natural gas and oil components to Baghdad. This proposal was sent to the Iraqi Parliament, triggering an impasse that has delayed the budget amendment yet again.

Soran Omar, a Kurdish member of the Iraqi Parliament, confirmed. According to Omar, the introduction of this new clause regarding the handover of oil and gas resources has complicated the discussions, leading to the lack of approval for the amendment. He stated, â€œThis new proposal by the Prime Minister has caused problems, and the amendment was not approved as a result.â€

The new clause is part of the Iraqi government's efforts to secure control over the oil and gas resources in the Kurdistan Region, which has long been a source of tension between Erbil and Baghdad. While the KRG has maintained its autonomy in managing these resources, the Iraqi government insists on more centralized control as part of its national economic strategy.

The parliamentary session on January 19, 2025, also saw the rejection of a proposal concerning the Kurdistan Regionâ€™s oil exports. This proposal aimed to set a provisional payment rate of $16 per barrel for the region's oil production and transportation. The Finance Committee had reviewed the amendment, which would have provided financial relief to the Kurdistan Region, but it was met with strong opposition from Shiite lawmakers. 
â¡ï¸( This is not the HCL Law BTW It is the $16 per barrel is payment from the federal government to the KRG for oil, which would then be adjusted against what the KRG owes the Iraqi federal government )

Omar explained that the vote could not take place because the quorum requirement for legal attendance was not met. Shiite legislators argued that $16 per barrel was an excessive amount compared to the $8 per barrel allocated for oil production in southern Iraq. However, KRG leaders had previously insisted on a higher rate of $26 per barrel due to the elevated costs of oil extraction in the region, leading to the compromise figure of $16. 

Escalation of Oil Smuggling Activities

Amidst these political disagreements, there has been a significant increase in oil smuggling activities from the Kurdistan Region to neighboring countries, particularly Iran and Turkey. Following the closure of the official export pipeline in March 2023, a clandestine network has emerged, facilitating the transport of oil via tanker trucks.

Reports indicate that over 1,000 tankers are involved in transporting at least 200,000 barrels of oil daily. This illicit trade is estimated to generate approximately $200 million per month.The oil is sold at significantly reduced prices, ranging between $30 to $40 per barrel, roughly half the global market rate. Despite the substantial revenue generated, the proceeds from these operations are not accounted for in the official coffers of the KRG, raising concerns about transparency and governance. 
â¡ï¸( KRG is not sending this to the Iraqi federal government, like all the other Regional Governments in Iraq do)

The smuggling operations have also attracted international attention due to potential violations of sanctions, particularly those imposed by the United States on Iran. The unregulated nature of these transactions poses significant risks, including environmental hazards and the undermining of official economic channels.

Implications for Regional Stability

The deadlock on the budget amendment, coupled with the surge in oil smuggling, has exacerbated the financial crisis in the Kurdistan Region. With official oil revenues suspended and no legal export avenues available, the region faces mounting economic challenges.

Tensions between the Iraqi federal government and the KRG continue to escalate, with implications for both regional stability and the international oil companies operating within the Kurdistan Region.The KRG is under increasing pressure, with lawmakers warning that the unresolved budget issue could lead to further economic difficulties and deepen the rift between Erbil and Baghdad.

Soran Omer have also expressed concern that the failure to pass the budget amendment could lead to the continuation of illicit oil sales, a practice that could undermine the region's economic recovery while depriving its citizens of much-needed revenue. The ongoing standoff between the two sides shows no signs of resolution, leaving the Kurdistan Region in a vulnerable position with little prospect for a swift solution.

What would happen if Trump imposed tariffs on Canadian crude oil?

Tariffs would make Canadian crude oil too expensive to supply to US refiners, which would have to replace Canadian crude oil with heavy crude oil imported from Latin America or the Middle East.

~90% of Canadian crude oil exported to the US is transported via pipeline systems, and the majority is WCS grade, which is heavy sour crude oil. 

TMX accounts for only 5% of the flow. ~200 kb/d of TMX volume will be re-routed to head from Vancouver to North Asia, and this change in flow is bullish for freight rates.

Tariffs could reduce Canadian crude oil production. If demand for WCS from the PADD 2 refineries decreases, Canada will need alternative sales outlets because the Vancouver alternative route has limited capacity. Therefore, it will have to export through USGC ports.

However, it is unlikely that all of these large volumes will be accepted by USGC ports. The fact that US light oil production has reached its limit is also related to the limited export capacity, and more crude oil will be converted to exports as the LyondellBasell refinery begins to shut down.

Therefore, it is not possible to export all of the volumes over 3mb/d that are subject to tariffs through USGC ports. 

Combining the existing ~4mb/d of WTI exports and ~3.5mb/d of Canadian crude oil exports amounts to ~7.5mb/d, which is well in excess of the USGC export capacity.

In conclusion, there will be a shortage of at least 1.5mb/d of Canadian crude oil export routes. 

As a result, either Canada must reduce production or the marginal cost of importing US crude oil must rise sharply. American taxpayers will be forced to pay for the massive increase in fuel prices.

Therefore, Trump's imposition of tariffs on Canadian crude oil is not easy. If he really does it, he's crazy.

$TSLA - Trade Review

This is Oversold bounce at key level

Setup - 
1. Identify Oversold - I do not use RSI, for me visual is enough, but for starters, folks can use RSI @ 15-minute granularity. Look at the historical chart to see the turning points.

2. Identify major and minor key levels - I used 350 as it is psych level and also minor higher-low
3. Do not rush into entries at open

Entries
3.  I used Bookmap to identify the liquidity zone. 350 was lining up with my level and liquidity (Refer to bookmap chart)
4. How the stock reacts near the level is essential. 
Two things that I look for
      a. Low volume into or near the level -
      b. Selling high volume and recapture
5. I tend to predict low of the day and keep my entries close to it

Stop
6. Low of the day if buying after the recapture 
or
7. Below the band if aggressive entry - I used 349

Trade Management
8. Trim > 5R (if possible), the region for trim is prior level if any for example 360 to 363 was previous zone, 
361 will trigger red to green move, so I took my profit 75 (Blue line).  This is a 5R first trim

9. Raising stop -left it as is

Tesla is bracing for a potential delay in obtaining Chinese approval for its autonomous driving technology, as Elon Muskâ€™s electric-vehicle company risks getting dragged into the escalating US-China trade war. 

The company has been told there is no definitive timetable for regulators to approve a licence for it to begin widespread training of its â€œfull self-drivingâ€ (FSD) technology, despite an earlier indication that it would get the green light in the second quarter of 2025, people with knowledge of the matter told the Financial Times. 

The licence would be an important step towards $TSLA being able to offer semi-autonomous functionality in its vehicles in China, a development that would boost subscription revenues and help shore up its shrinking sales in the worldâ€™s largest automotive market.

The system can accelerate, steer, brake and change lanes but still requires drivers to be alert with their hands on the wheel. 

Tesla had announced in September that it planned to roll out FSD technology in China and Europe in the first quarter of 2025, subject to regulatory approval.

That ambition had already slipped and is now in greater doubt as US President Donald Trump engages in a trade war with China. Beijing imposed retaliatory tariffs on a range of American goods this month after the US put an additional 10% levy on all Chinese products. 

Chinese authorities are contemplating using the approval of Teslaâ€™s autonomous-driving licence as a bargaining chip in trade negotiations with Trump, said two of the people with knowledge of the delay, adding that this was the main reason for the hold-up in granting the permit. 

The approval could still come soon, depending on how trade negotiations developed, one of the people added. But another said that some people at the company believed a speedy consent was unlikely unless there was â€œa major breakthrough or concessionâ€ in trade talks.

In June, Shanghai allowed FSD testing by 10 Tesla vehicles as a precursor to a wider rollout across China, while Tesla also struck a deal last year to use systems from tech group Baidu, which offers navigation and mapping. 

However, Musk said last month that Tesla was â€œin a bit of a bindâ€ as it tried to deploy FSD in China, stuck between Beijing and Washingtonâ€™s strict data security rules. 

FSD is based on a machine learning system that is fed billions of hours of video to train an algorithm to make driving decisions in real time. 

â€œThey wonâ€™t currently allow us to transfer training video outside of China. And then the US government wonâ€™t let us do training in China,â€ said Musk on Teslaâ€™s latest earnings call. â€œItâ€™s a bit of a quandary.â€

How Are Real World Assets Tokenized on Plume?

Tokenization turns real world assets (RWAs) â€“ like oil, real estate, or solar energy farms â€“ into digital tokens on the blockchain, making them easier to buy, sell, and trade.

But how does the process actually work, and can it be trusted?

1. Verify the Asset
The asset is checked for ownership, value, and legal status before being tokenized. Plume Arc simplifies this process by providing a unified platform with 50+ modular features for registering RWAs onchain.

2. Ensure Compliance
RWAs must follow financial laws. Plume Arc integrates compliance tools like KYC/KYB, custody, and on/off-ramps, ensuring assets meet regulations from day one.

3. Create Digital Tokens
The asset is converted into crypto tokens, which can be fractionalized so more people can buy them.

4. Trade and Manage Tokens
Tokens can be bought, sold, or transferred instantly. Plume Nexus Data Highway ensures accurate, real-time data flow, keeping asset information secure and up to date.

5. Hold or Redeem the Asset
Users can trade tokens, hold them, or redeem them for the real asset. Code in smart contracts automates transactions safely without needing any middle parties.

Plume makes it easier for businesses to bring RWAs onchain

Tokenization makes RWAs more accessible, but challenges like regulations, technical complexity, and liquidity have slowed adoption. Plumeâ€™s full-stack solution solves this with:

TRUMP ADMIN ASKED IRAQ TO RESUME KURDISH OIL EXPORTS QUICKLY OR FACE SANCTIONS ALONGSIDE IRAN - REUTERS

ğŸ”¥ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡¶The United States of America threatened, today, Friday, February 21, 2025, the federal government in Iraq with sanctions if the Kurdistan Region's oil exports are not resumed quickly.

Reuters quoted sources as saying: "The administration of President Donald Trump asked Iraq to resume (Kurdish) oil exports quickly or face sanctions alongside Iran."

The sources added, according to Reuters, that "Washington believes that Kurdish oil sales may help reduce crude prices and compensate for the decline in Iranian supplies."

Oil Minister Hayan Abdul Ghani revealed on Tuesday that Iraq had sent a delegation from the ministry to the Kurdistan Region to agree on a mechanism for delivering the regionâ€™s oil and exporting it through the Turkish port of Ceyhan.

The Minister of Oil explained that he had contacted the Minister of Natural Resources in the region, Kamal Mohammed Saleh, to negotiate with the delegation about the mechanism for receiving and exporting oil through the Turkish port of Ceyhan.

This came a day after Iraq accelerated the expected date for the resumption of oil exports from Kurdistan, as the federal oil minister said last Monday that oil exports from the Kurdistan region could resume within just a week.

It is noteworthy that the President of the Region, Nechirvan Barzani, announced a few days ago that the resumption of shipments will likely take place next March.

Iraq exports between 400,000 and 500,000 barrels per day from fields in the north of the country, including the Kurdistan region, via the now-defunct Iraq-Turkey pipeline.

Oil Minister Hayan Abdul Ghani said earlier this month that at least 300,000 barrels per day of crude were planned to be moved once operations resumed.

In Iraqi Kurdistan, oil production ranges between about 280,000 and 300,000 barrels per day, and the regional government estimates its needs for domestic consumption - including power generation - at about 110,000 to 120,000 barrels per day.

Iraqi PM Stresses Resumption of Kurdistanâ€™s Oil Export

Al-Sudani called on oil companies in the Kurdistan Region to immediately resume production and facilitate exports through Ceyhan port

Iraqi Prime Minister Mohammed Shia al-Sudani has emphasized the urgency of resuming oil production in the Kurdistan Region and restarting exports through the Turkish port of Ceyhan.
He underscored the necessity of moving forward with joint economic agreements, particularly following the recent amendments to the Federal Budget Law passed by the Iraqi Parliament.
Al-Sudani Stresses Economic Cooperation
In a statement released on Saturday, the Iraqi Prime Ministerâ€™s Office confirmed that Al-Sudani met with Kurdistan Region President Nechirvan Barzani to discuss key national issues.
The discussions focused on economic cooperation, energy policies, and the implementation of the federal governmentâ€™s agenda across various sectors.
Urgent Need for Oil Exports Through Ceyhan
During the meeting, Al-Sudani stressed that restarting Kurdistanâ€™s oil exports is a national priority, noting that its suspension has impacted Iraqâ€™s overall economy.
He called on oil companies in the Kurdistan Region to immediately resume production and facilitate exports through Ceyhan port, ensuring economic stability and fulfilling Iraqâ€™s financial obligations.
President Barzani Reaffirms Commitment to Coordination
For his part, President Nechirvan Barzani reiterated the Kurdistan Regional Governmentâ€™s (KRG) commitment to working closely with Baghdad.
He highlighted the importance of maintaining coordination between the two governments in economic, financial, and service-related matters, which he said is essential for long-term stability and development.
Impact of Oil Export Suspension on Iraqâ€™s Economy
Kurdistanâ€™s oil exports have been halted since March 2023, following legal and political disputes between Baghdad, Erbil, and Ankara.
The prolonged suspension has placed significant financial strain on both the regional and federal economies. The renewed dialogue between Baghdad and Erbil is seen as a crucial step toward resolving longstanding disputes and restoring the country's vital energy sector operations.

SULAIMANI, Kuridstan Region â€“ Baghdad and Erbil have reached an agreement to resume oil exports from the Kurdistan Region, following discussions between the Federal Ministry of Oil and the Kurdistan Regional Governmentâ€™s (KRG) Ministry of Natural Resources.
In a statement, the KRG Ministy of Natural Resources announced a joint technical team has been formed to inspect and assess the Kurdistan Region oil export pipelines.
Oil exports from the Region were halted in March 2023 after a ruling by the International Chamber of Commerce ordered Turkey to stop the flow of Kurdistanâ€™s crude through the Iraq-Turkey pipeline.

ERBIL (Kurdistan24) â€“Â In a significant breakthrough, Erbil and Baghdad have reached an agreement to resume the Kurdistan Regionâ€™s oil exports, marking a step toward resolving a longstanding economic and political dispute.
As part of the agreement, a joint technical committee has been formed to inspect and assess Kurdistanâ€™s oil export pipelines.
The Kurdistan Regional Governmentâ€™s (KRG) negotiating delegation announced the agreement on Sunday, emphasizing that it was reached following extensive communications and coordination between the Iraqi Federal Oil Ministry and the Kurdistan Regionâ€™s Ministry of Natural Resources (MoNR).
According to the statement, oil exports will resume in accordance with available quantities, ensuring a gradual return to international markets.
To facilitate this process, a joint technical team was established on Sunday to conduct inspections on Kurdistanâ€™s oil export pipelines. This step is aimed at ensuring the smooth and efficient flow of oil exports, which have been suspended for nearly two years.
â€œIn this regard, we reaffirm our commitment to implementing the provisions of the federal general budget law,â€ the KRG delegation stated, signaling a commitment to the legal and regulatory framework governing oil revenues and resource management in Iraq.
The agreement follows an announcement by the Iraqi Oil Ministry on Saturday stating that all necessary procedures for resuming Kurdistanâ€™s oil exports via Turkeyâ€™s Ceyhan port have been completed.
Read More:Â Iraq and Kurdistan Region Finalize Mechanism to Resume Oil Exports
This development paves the way for Kurdistanâ€™s crude oil to re-enter international markets, stabilizing the regionâ€™s energy sector and restoring a crucial revenue stream for both Erbil and Baghdad.
The halt in Kurdistanâ€™s oil exports, which lasted nearly two years, has had profound economic ramifications, resulting in an estimated $26 billion in losses for both Iraq and the Kurdistan Region.
The prolonged suspension also disrupted global energy markets, exacerbating supply chain challenges and economic uncertainty.
Reports by Reuters, citing eight different sources, previously suggested that the Trump administration had urged Iraq to expedite the resumption of Kurdistanâ€™s oil exports, highlighting the geopolitical and economic significance of Kurdish crude in the broader energy landscape.
As Erbil and Baghdad move forward with the technical implementation of this agreement, attention will be focused on ensuring transparency and efficiency in oil export operations.
The resumption of exports is expected to provide much-needed financial relief to the Kurdistan Region while also strengthening the broader economic ties between the federal and regional governments.

â€œRising US Oil Imports: Sectoral Winners and Losers in Indiaâ€™s Economyâ€

Indiaâ€™s crude oil imports from the United States surged to 218,400 barrels per day (bpd) in January 2025, a sharp increase from 70,600 bpd in December 2024. This development aligns with the observation from our earlier post*â€”India is strategically adjusting its import sources in response to trade deficit concerns raised by the new US administration.

Over the course of 2025, Indiaâ€™s crude oil and natural gas imports from the US is expected to reach $25 billion, up from $15 billion in 2024, as per recent government messaging. However, this shift is expected to come at the expense of Russian imports, as the US deploys energy-related sanctions to curb Moscowâ€™s revenue streams and pressure them to end the war in Ukraine. For India, this transition carries substantial economic implications, particularly as Russian crude was available at a 15-20% discount to global market prices, significantly reducing our fuel bill over the past two years.

While increased crude procurement costs are likely to push up Indiaâ€™s fuel expenses, the direct impact on Wholesale Price Index (WPI) inflation needs to be assessed in a broader context. One silver lining is that WPI inflation has been cooling in recent months, declining from 3.43% in June 2024 to 2.31% in January 2025.

A key factor providing relief is the downward trend in food pricesâ€”which hold a 15% weight in WPI. The WPI food inflation rate has eased to 5.8% in January 2025, down from 6.9% year-on-year, driven by normalizing supply chains and improved crop yields. This could help cushion the impact of rising crude costs on overall inflation.

Analyzing major market sectors by their crude price sensitivity reveals three distinct segments. These sectors can either be producers or consumers of the WPI components, i.e. the nature of their exposure (to crude prices) differs based on their role in different supply chains.

High impact sectors, where crude or its derivatives serve as direct input material. This includes oil marketing companies, refineries, petrochemicals, and synthetic textiles which face direct margin pressure due to higher crude prices.

Medium impact sectors include industries where crude oil complements the core production process, but isn't a direct input. The cement sector and airlines are examples, where crude oil and its derivatives play an enabling role in the production process or service being offered.

Low impact sectors are those where crude primarily influences transportation costsâ€”both for raw materials and finished goods. This encompasses metals, FMCG, pharmaceuticals, and most agricultural commodities. These sectors face limited direct exposure to crude price variations.

This analysis suggests that while higher US crude import costs will affect different sectors disproportionately, the impact on overall WPI might be moderated by strong agricultural performance expected this year. Hence, this should not have a significant bearing on the RBIâ€™s monetary policy trajectory.

Basis Trade Vaults are coming with @Lombard_Finance and @ether_fi.

The Idea
Bitcoin is digital gold, Ethereum is digital oil. They're fundamental assets yet, they often sit idle missing yield. In 2023/24, basis trading and LSTs surged in popularity; unlocking new layers of yield. Now we take it one step further.

Enter basis trading vaults. Idle LSTs/LRTs are combined with staking rewards and a delta=1 basis trade. Unlike traditional basis strategies that hedge out price movements, these vaults keep full exposure to BTC and ETH; meaning you still benefit from price appreciation while earning yield from funding spreads.

The Strategy
A basis trade exploits the difference between spot and perpetual futures prices. The vault mechanics are straightforward:
â¤ Deposit. Provide LBTC or weETH as collateral.
â¤ Leverage & Hedge. Borrow stablecoins, buy more LBTC/weETH (Derive secret sauce), and short perps to lock in the basis spread.
â¤ Earn. Collect staking rewards, funding rate differentials, and amplified points from atomic execution.

What if the market moves against me?
The strategy stays hedged. Holding 2 LBTC or weETH against a $100k debt stays safe even if BTC/ETH 100xâ€™s or drops 90%. Gains on one leg offset losses on the other; price is a non-issue. The only pricing risk is a depeg.

What if funding flips or borrowing costs spike? 
If perp funding turns negative or stablecoin borrow rates rise, the system automatically reduces leverage to avoid prolonged negative carry.

Are there any liquidity risks?
In cases of low spot or perp liquidity, the vault may take longer to exit positions, potentially resulting in brief periods of negative funding.

The Yield
â¤ Perp Funding (est. 10-20%) â€“ Borrow Rate (5-10%) = Basis Yield
â¤ Leveraged LBTC & weETH Staking + Points = Additional APR
â¤ Compounded, this turns idle BTC & ETH into a more efficient yield engine.

Basis trading has long been a staple in TradFi, generating steady, predictable returns by capturing spreads between spot and futures markets. Now, with yield-bearing collateral like LSTs and LRTs, the strategy is being automated for DeFi.

Institutions are taking note. As the market matures, structured, delta-neutral strategies are moving from niche to necessity. More to follow.

ğŸ”¹ A surety in payments refers to a person or entity that guarantees the payment of a debt or obligation if the primary party responsible for the payment fails to fulfill their obligation. The surety provides financial security to the creditor, ensuring that the payment will be made even if the debtor defaults. ğŸ”» 
ğŸ”¸ A Surety Bond - A guarantee issued by a third party (such as an insurance company or bank) to ensure that a contractual obligation, such as a payment, will be met.
ğŸ”¸ A Guarantor - An individual or company that agrees to cover the debt if the primary borrower defaults.

ğŸ”¹ A surety in payments is a legally binding agreement. When a person or entity (the surety) agrees to guarantee the payment obligations of another party (the principal), they are legally obligated to fulfill the payment if the principal defaults. The terms of the surety agreement are typically outlined in a contract, which defines the responsibilities of the principal, the surety, and the creditor (the beneficiary). If the principal fails to meet their obligations, the creditor can legally enforce the surety's commitment to pay.

End of week thoughts: President Trumpâ€™s tariff tango keeps the market guessing on which foot to dance.

OPEC+ trusted its oil balance enough to initiate the unwinding of voluntary cuts, or alternatively, it could be argued that OPEC+ sent an olive branch to President Trump to show it was doing its part, without losing face, in helping to bring the oil price down. Take your pick; it does not matter as the small incremental volume to be reinstated in the coming months is irrelevant in the larger scheme of things, given the gross non-compliance by member countries like the UAE or Iraq. The global oil balance is long in 2025, so the optics of OPEC+â€™s decision wrong-footing expectations were inevitably going to be treated as price-negative from a sentiment point of view. ICE Brent briefly traded under $69/bbl as a result. That should tell you something. Todayâ€™s comments by Russian Deputy Prime Minister Novak about OPEC+ potentially reducing output to address any â€œimbalanceâ€ in the future to shore up sentiment fell on deaf ears.

President Trumpâ€™s tariff tango kept the market guessing on which foot to dance. Aggressive US economic and foreign policy offset each other in terms of oil price impact this week. On the one hand, the imposition of tariffs on Canada and Mexico seems to be now complicated by the provisions of the USMCA trade accord, and the timeline is consistently shifting it seems, as is what will fall under tariffs. Add to that President Trump touted the possibility of reciprocal tariffs being introduced as soon as today, and you have bearish cocktail for price. On the other hand, US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent provided bullish fodder, and he did not mince his words indicating the US would be prepared to reduce Iranian crude oil exports to a trickle and cripple Iranâ€™s economy under a maximum pressure policy â€“ hard to say if the US is really going â€˜all-inâ€™ or is this the usual waiving of the big stick again to advance an alternative agenda. Mr Bessent's comments managed to pull Brent out from the $60 handle doldrums, sending the front-month ICE contract towards $71.50/bbl.

However, the end-of-week price action would not have been complete without President Putin. Headlines emerged today indicating that Russia would be prepared to talk about a temporary truce in the Ukraine War if there was progress towards a final peace settlement. Flat price fell towards $70.25/bbl at the time of writing. For all the gyrations in the flat price this week, prompt Brent time-spreads have not collapsed and are holding at 50 cents, which should provide OPEC with some comfort that the wheels have not yet come off the fundamental cart. With steady spreads, the curve is trying to find a new level amidst the general uncertainty, so expect more parallel shifts in the curve until market sentiment settles, assuming it can settle amidst the Trump whirlwind.

What's Trump's real plan for Alberta's oilsands?

Premier Smith pointed out that President Trump's proposed 10% tariffs on Canadian energy instead of 25% like other goods signifies the critical nature of Canadian oil for the United States.

The president previously floated the idea of reviving the Keystone XL pipeline project that was cancelled by the Biden administration. However President Trump has also repeatedly threatened to impose a 10% tariff on Canadian oil as well, although he walked back the threat yesterday.

@Dfildebrandt commented on the back-and-forth nature of Trump's messaging surrounding Canadian energy and what his real plans could be.

"I'm not sure there is understanding it," he said. "There's a 'mad dog' theory of Trump, that he's just throwing us off and softening us up, but I'm not seeing any strategy in this," he added.

Speaking specifically on Trump's tariff threats on Canadian oil, Fildebrandt was perplexed by Trump's thought process.

"It's not good for American refineries, it's not good for American energy independence...it doesn't square with Keystone XL, I'm just not seeing any strategy here," he said.

President Trump announced on Thursday that he would be scaling back some tariffs for Canada until at least April 2.

ğŸ”¥Iraq tells US: Stopping Iranian gas imports will cause electricity system to collapseğŸ”¥

On Sunday, the head of the Finance Committee in the Iraqi Parliament, Atwan Al-Atwani, sent a letter to the US government stating that stopping the import of gas from Iran will cause the collapse of the electricity grid system during the coming summer in Iraq, indicating the need to extend the exemptions granted to Iraq in this regard after they were officially stopped by the administration of US President Donald Trump.

This came during Al-Atwani's meeting with the US Ambassador to Iraq, Daniel Rubinstein, and the accompanying delegation, according to the MP's media office.

The head of the Parliamentary Finance Committee stressed the importance of this visit at this sensitive time, and stressed the need for continuous communication to correct the course of Iraqi-American relations.

The statement added that the meeting focused on discussing the US sanctions file and their impact on the electricity sector, especially in light of talk about the expiration of the deadline for Iraq to be exempted from importing Iranian gas.

The statement also indicated that Al-Atwani conveyed an important message to the US ambassador to his country's government, stating that stopping gas imports would have disastrous consequences for the Iraqi people, especially in the summer, as it would cause the collapse of the national electricity system, due to the lack of any alternatives at the present time.

Al-Atwani said during the meeting that the Iraqi government is serious about achieving energy independence through several promising projects related to investing in associated gas, for the purpose of using it in generating electricity and achieving self-sufficiency, but these projects will enter service in the coming years.

Al-Atwani also called on the US administration to review the policy of pressure exerted by the US Treasury on the financial and banking sector in Iraq by imposing continuous sanctions on local banks.

He pointed out that Iraq has achieved a qualitative shift in the policy of compliance and financial transfers, and despite that, we are surprised by collective sanctions targeting Iraqi banks without prior warning and without any declared justification or even notifying the Central Bank of Iraq about that, and this has created a major problem for us and affected the work and activity of the banking sector.

In turn, the US Ambassador expressed his understanding of what Al-Atwani had raised during the meeting regarding the energy and banking sanctions files, and promised to convey these messages to his country's government in the hope of finding permanent treatments and solutions that would achieve the interests of the two friendly peoples, noting that the import of natural gas is, until now, outside the sanctions system, according to the statement.

Rewriting his loss as some masterstroke win.

He builds his walls, he burns each bridge,  
A chaos-monger atop his ridge.  

But hereâ€™s the thing, Donnie boy:  
The world isnâ€™t your personal toy.  
Your temper tantrums wonâ€™t bend their knees,

ğŸ”¥ğŸ›¢ï¸Kirkuk is prepared to resume oil exports to Ceyhan, Turke pipline, pumping tests on March 16, was successful.

1. Kirkuk's Readiness to Resume Oil Exports
Announcement: Sources within the Iraqi North Oil Company (NOC) confirmed on Sunday, March 16, 2025, that Kirkuk is prepared to resume oil exports to Ceyhan, Turkey, at an initial rate of 100,000 barrels per day (bpd). An "experimental" pumping operation is underway to verify the pipeline's readiness.

Key Figures Involved: Amer Khalil Ahmed, the Director General of NOC, participated in meetings with Iraqâ€™s Deputy Prime Minister for Energy and Oil Minister Hayan Abdul Ghani, alongside Turkish Energy Minister Alparslan Bayraktar. These discussions affirmed NOCâ€™s technical readiness to restart exports.

Timeline: The resumption hinges on an official directive from the Federal Ministry of Oil. Once approved, NOC claims it can begin pumping within hours.

2. Pipeline Repairs After ISIS Damage
Repairs Completed: The Iraqi-Turkish pipeline, previously sabotaged by ISIS, has been fully repaired. The damaged sections between Kirkuk, Salahuddin, Nineveh, and the Iraqi-Turkish border have been fixed, with affected parts replaced.

Testing: NOC conducted successful two-stage pumping tests over a year ago:
Stage 1: From Kirkuk fields to Baiji refineries.
Stage 2: From Baiji through Nineveh to Dohuk, confirming the pipelineâ€™s 100% operational readiness.

3. Current Production and Allocation
Production Capacity: NOC currently produces around 250,000 bpd from Kirkuk fields.
Allocation:
10,000 bpd is exported to Jordan.
100,000 bpd is used for local refining.
Additional amounts supply private refineries in Erbil and Sulaymaniyah (Kurdistan Region) for gasoline and oil derivatives, as determined by the Ministry of Oil.

Export Potential: The initial export target is 100,000 bpd to Ceyhan, with the possibility of increasing this based on production and federal approval.

4. Negotiations and Delays
Dependency on Talks: The resumption of exports depends on ongoing negotiations between the Iraqi Ministry of Oil and Turkish authorities. While NOC is technically ready, political and financial agreements remain unresolved.

Turkish Visit: On March 16, 2025, Turkish Energy Minister Alparslan Bayraktar arrived in Baghdad to discuss oil, gas, and energy cooperation with Hayan Abdul Ghani, signaling progress but no final resolution yet.

The pipeline has been shut since March 2023, when Turkey halted flows after an arbitration ruling ordered it to pay Iraq $1.5 billion for facilitating unauthorized Kurdish oil exports (2014â€“2018) without Baghdadâ€™s consent. Turkey refused to pay, instead asking the Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG) to cover the fine, leading to a prolonged standoff.

5. Technical and Strategic Insights
Experimental Pumping: Energy specialist Yusef Mahmoud emphasized that the current pilot pumping assesses the pipelineâ€™s safety and the readiness of pumping stations, critical after repeated ISIS attacks.

Potential Impact: Resuming exports could stabilize Iraqâ€™s oil shipments (previously 400,000â€“500,000 bpd from northern fields, including Kurdistan) and ease market pressures. Iraq aims to export at least 300,000 bpd once operations restart, with Kirkuk oil designated for local use and Kurdistan oil potentially flowing through Ceyhan.

6. OPEC Compliance and Future Plans
Ministerâ€™s Statements: On February 24, 2025, Hayan Abdul Ghani said that Iraq awaits Turkeyâ€™s approval to restart Kurdistan oil exports, potentially within days. He clarified that Kirkuk oil would remain for domestic use, while exports would focus on Kurdistan production.

OPEC Commitment: Abdul Ghani assured that Iraqâ€™s OPEC+ obligations would be maintained, with export volumes controlled by the federal ministry via the State Oil Marketing Company (SOMO).

Difference Between Kirkuk and Kurdistan Oil Flows
The  two distinct oil production and export systems in northern Iraq: Kirkuk (managed by the federal government via NOC) and the Kurdistan Region (managed by the KRG). Hereâ€™s how they differ:

1. Ownership and Control
Kirkuk Oil:
Controlled by the Iraqi federal government through the North Oil Company, a state-owned entity under the 
Ministry of Oil.
Fields are located in Kirkuk province, a disputed area between Baghdad and the KRG but currently administered by federal authorities.
Oil is subject to federal policies, including allocation for local refining, exports to Jordan, and potential exports via Ceyhan, all managed by SOMO.

Kurdistan Oil:
Managed by the semi-autonomous Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG) through its Ministry of Natural Resources.
Produced from fields within the Kurdistan Region (e.g., Taq Taq, Tawke), separate from Kirkuk.
Historically exported independently by the KRG via a dedicated pipeline to Ceyhan, bypassing federal control, which led to disputes with Baghdad.

2. Pipeline Infrastructure
Kirkuk Oil:
Uses the Iraqi-Turkish pipeline (Kirkuk-Ceyhan pipeline), a federal asset repaired by NOC after ISIS damage. This pipeline runs from Kirkuk through Salahuddin, Nineveh, and Dohuk to the Turkish border, then to Ceyhan.
Capacity was historically higher (up to 1.6 million bpd), but current flows are limited by repairs and federal decisions (targeting 100,000 bpd initially).

Kurdistan Oil:
Uses a separate KRG-built pipeline connecting Kurdish fields (e.g., Taq Taq, Khurmala) to the federal Kirkuk-Ceyhan pipeline at the Turkish border (Fish-Khabur).
Before the 2023 shutdown, it exported 370,000â€“450,000 bpd, significantly more than Kirkukâ€™s current contribution.

3. Export Volumes and Purpose
Kirkuk Oil:
Current production is 250,000 bpd, with most allocated domestically (100,000 bpd for refining, 10,000 bpd to Jordan). Only 100,000 bpd is proposed for export initially, with Abdul Ghani stating itâ€™s primarily for local use.
Exports are fully integrated into Iraqâ€™s OPEC+ quotas and federal revenue system.

Kurdistan Oil:
Pre-2023 exports ranged from 400,000â€“500,000 bpd, including Kurdish production and some federal oil from Kirkuk fields.
The KRG aimed to export independently for regional revenue, but Baghdad insists all exports go through SOMO, creating a legal and financial conflict.
4. Legal and Political Disputes

Kirkuk Oil:
Fully under federal jurisdiction, with no significant legal disputes over its export via Ceyhan once technical and diplomatic hurdles are cleared.

Kurdistan Oil:
Subject to a long-standing dispute with Baghdad, exacerbated by the 2023 arbitration ruling against Turkey for facilitating KRG exports without federal approval. This led to the pipeline closure and ongoing talks to align KRG exports with SOMO.
5. Impact of Resumption

Kirkuk Oil:
Restarting exports at 100,000 bpd would boost federal revenue and demonstrate NOCâ€™s operational capacity, but itâ€™s a smaller-scale operation compared to past northern exports.

Kurdistan Oil:
Resuming 300,000â€“450,000 bpd would significantly impact KRGâ€™s economy (reliant on oil revenue) and global supply, but it requires resolving payment disputes with oil companies and Turkeyâ€™s $1.5 billion fine.

 Kirkukâ€™s technical readiness to export 100,000 bpd via the repaired Iraqi-Turkish pipeline, pending federal and Turkish approval. Meanwhile, Kurdistanâ€™s larger export potential (300,000+ bpd) remains stalled due to political and financial disputes. Kirkuk oil is federally controlled and prioritized for local use, while Kurdistan oil, managed by the KRG, seeks independent export channels, creating a complex dynamic in Iraqâ€™s northern oil strategy. The experimental pumping on March 16, 2025, is a step toward resuming Kirkuk flows, but broader resumption hinges on Baghdad-Ankara negotiations.

ERBIL (Kurdistan24) â€“ In a key step toward resolving the ongoing oil export dispute, the Iraqi parliament is set to discuss the issue of the Kurdistan Regionâ€™s oil exports on Wednesday.Â 
Sabah Subhi, a member of the Iraqi Parliament's Oil and Gas Committee, confirmed to Kurdistan24 that the committee will host a delegation from the Ministry of Oil to address the challenges facing the Kurdistan Region's oil exports. The discussions will cover the latest developments, ongoing measures, and the relationship between the Ministry of Oil and the Association of the Petroleum Industry of Kurdistan (APIKUR).Â 
"As the Oil and Gas Committee in Parliament, we will request a clear explanation from the Ministry of Oil regarding the delay in resuming exports from the Kurdistan Region," Subhi stated.Â 
While an agreement has yet to be reached between the Iraqi Oil Ministry, the Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG), and APIKUR, both sides have agreed to hold further meetings to work toward a resolution. However, APIKUR companies have expressed concerns about the current export mechanism proposed by the Iraqi Oil Ministry.Â 
The upcoming discussions in parliament signal a renewed effort to find common ground, with hopes that a breakthrough will soon allow the resumption of vital oil exports from the Kurdistan Region.

China Strikes at Canadian Exports: Farmers on the Brink of Survival

As of March 8, China has officially imposed new tariffs on key Canadian goods â€” and farmers are sounding the alarm. Canola oil, meal, and peas now face a 100% tariff, while pork and seafood are hit with a 25% tariff. Experts warn these measures could devastate the agricultural sector and jeopardize thousands of jobs.

Chinaâ€™s actions come in retaliation to Canadaâ€™s recently introduced tariffs: 100% on Chinese electric vehicles and 25% on aluminum and steel products. Itâ€™s an economic war between the two nations. Canada sought to protect its auto industry from dumping â€” cheap electric vehicles mass-produced in China with state support. In response, Beijing hit Canadian farmers, who have already been struggling for years due to drought, high costs, and unstable incomes.

Canola, in particular, has been hit hard â€” a crop that for years ensured stable exports to China. According to Tara Sawyer, chair of Grain Growers of Canada, these new tariffs effectively close the Chinese market. She, like thousands of other farmers, was preparing for spring planting but is now counting losses and fearing for the future of her farm.

Economists confirm: the tariffs will not only slash profits but also lead to market oversupply, price drops, and the potential bankruptcy of many producers. Professor Daniel Trefler of the University of Toronto called the canola tariff â€œa punishment devised by the Chinese regime,â€ warning of severe consequences for regions where agriculture is a way of life.

Seafood is also at risk: Canada exports over $1.3 billion in fish to China annually. Unique products like British Columbiaâ€™s scallops and Nova Scotiaâ€™s elvers are almost entirely reliant on the Chinese market. The Fisheries Council of Canada has already stated that tariffs from both China and the U.S. are effectively cutting Canada off from 83% of the global seafood market.

Even pork producers are feeling the blow: China was Canadaâ€™s third-largest pork buyer, purchasing over $43 million worth annually. Canadian Federation of Agriculture president Keith Currie openly said these tariffs hit at the worst possible time.

In response, the federal government has promised support: Agriculture Minister Cody Blois is in talks with the governments of Alberta and Saskatchewan to activate existing risk-management programs. Alberta has already earmarked $4 billion to address economic challenges. Premier Danielle Smith even joked sheâ€™s â€œdoubled her bacon consumption in solidarity.â€ Meanwhile, Saskatchewan and Nova Scotia have yet to propose concrete actions, offering only optimistic statements.

Amid all this, farmers are not just calculating financial losses but struggling under immense psychological pressure. â€œEveryoneâ€™s on edge. Things change every day, and we donâ€™t know whatâ€™s coming,â€ Sawyer admits.

Canada is caught in a complex geopolitical game. While defending its interests, itâ€™s paying a steep price. The real question is whether the country can stand by its producers in this moment â€” or leave them to face global giants alone.

Inflation Is Down, Lumber Is Up

Scott Choppin Note: 

Some good news for construction costs.

General inflation is down. Oil is down 14%. 

Lumber will be one exception to this news. New US Lumber tariffs will match or exceed historical Canadian tariffs of around 15%. Generally, US construction markets bought 60-70% of lumber from domestic markets, the rest from Canada. Presently, lumber futures are up 21% on this news, mostly related to supply constraints and builders stockpiling due to near term disruption concerns. 

One caveat, equal and opposite tariffs often produce negotiation by the countries to eliminate tariffs. I could see this happening on lumber early in that potential process.

I promised to post this as we talked about this on my stocks / options space earlier today.

The trade is the bull call

Itâ€™s a lower cost alternative to the long call with some advantages and disadvantages 

Letâ€™s you were looking at buying a long call on TSLA ( this is simply an example and not a recommendation to do this trade)

A strike 250 call for April 17 is $17.85

Works great if the stock moves up quickly. What if the call premium is more than you can afford and you would like to be able to give the stock a little more time to move in your direction.

Then use the bull call 

Here is the trade

Buy the April 17 250 call

Sell the April 17 255 call

Your cost is $2.35 instead of $17.85 and you can see that in the image

Advantages

Much lower cost

The time decay ( theta) of the long call by itself is offset by the short call so the passage of time doesnâ€™t hurt you. This gives the stock more time to move in your direction.

Disadvantages

Your profit is capped at 100% 

If the stock moves up explosively then you would make way more in a long call by itself.

Note 

You can do a version of this for a long put as well

Buy a long put

Sell a long put one strike below it.

US President #DonaldTrump announces 25% tariff on countries buying #Venezuelan oil 

How it will impact India?
https://t.co/jZBp43waZK

President Trump announced 25% tariffs on every country that imports Venezuelan oil.

- Over the last year, there are approximately 195 cargos of Venezuelan oil exported from Venezuela to Europe.

- If you add up China - that's another 90 cargos.

Here's why it matters:

The US is actually introducing a new type of secondary sanctions: it used to be the fact that if you trade in sanctioned cargos- you might end up on the blacklist. For good or bad - -there is a legal bar / onus to that . it's not that automatic to get someone on the "full blacklist" (especially in the EU). Also , the accountability was per *company* - a private company could get in or out of the sanctions list.

Now, the US is introducing a *Country* level "punishment" - 25% tariff on *countries* of which *companies* import Venezuelan oil. I of course get why this could be effective.

As a member of the @RUSI_org  Maritime Sanctions Taskforce and UK Sanctions Taskforce- this is a big development. It changes time to get sanctioned, accountability and reversibility. Sanctions were always part of the geopolitical game, but now the pace has been upped 10x.

Being here in Singapore and listening to the speakers and the regional players- I believe there is a worry about unpredictability of decisions , cause and effect and its lasting impact on world trade.

Source: @WindwardAI  , @CNBC  : https://t.co/nqAxiE786d

THREAD: Auto Tariffs = Big Winners & Losers (25% on Foreign-Made Cars)
If Trumpâ€™s 25% import tariff hits, hereâ€™s the breakdown for investors â€” which stocks to watch and which to avoid:
$TSLA $GM $F $STLA $TM $HMC $MBGYY $VLVOF
(1/)

Winners:

1. $TSLA (Tesla)
Built in the USA. Zero import exposure.
25% tariff would give Tesla a major price edge vs. foreign EVs like the BMW i4 or Hyundai Ioniq 6.
(2/)

2. $GM (General Motors)
Massive U.S. manufacturing footprint. Strong SUV/truck portfolio benefits as foreign competitors get priced out.
(3/)

3. $F (Ford)
Same story as GM. Dominates in high-margin U.S.-built trucks. Any tariff tilts the playing field in Fordâ€™s favor.
(4/)

4. $STLA (Stellantis)
Jeep, RAM, and Dodge production is largely domestic. Despite being HQâ€™d in Europe, key models dodge the tariff hit.
(5/)

5. $DAN, $BWA, $AXL
Auto parts suppliers based in the U.S. stand to gain if OEMs reshore production. Watch Dana Inc, BorgWarner, American Axle.
(6/)

6. $KMX (CarMax)
Used car dealers benefit from new car price inflation. Tariffs = more buyers switching to used inventory.
(7/)

â¸»

Losers:

1. $MBGYY (Mercedes), $VLVOF (Volvo), $BMWYY (BMW)
Luxury automakers with high U.S. exposure but mostly foreign production. Imports get slapped with a 25% hike. Margins squeezed.
(8/)

2. $TM (Toyota) and $HMC (Honda)
U.S. production helps, but not enough. Imports like Land Cruiser, Prius, and some CR-V/HR-V trims face price hikes.
(9/)

3. Hyundai/Kia (Not U.S.-listed)
Still heavily import-reliant. Models like the Genesis G80, Hyundai Tucson, Kia EV6 would get more expensive overnight.
(10/)

4. U.S. dealerships repping import brands
Higher sticker prices = fewer buyers = lower dealer margins. Watch out for softening sales at Audi, Mazda, Hyundai dealerships.
(11/)

â¸»

Macro Takeaway:
â€¢BUY: $TSLA, $GM, $F, $STLA, $DAN, $AXL
â€¢CAUTION: $TM, $HMC, $MBGYY, $BMWYY
â€¢Tariffs are inflationary: Consumers lose. Used car stocks win.
â€¢Election catalyst: This trade could move fast on policy headlines.
(12/)

The countries hit hardest by Trump's 25% auto tariff are undoubtedly Japan and South Korea, especially Japan.

Japan and South Korea have already faced direct fierce competition from the rising Chinese EV on a global scale, and the US market is basically their only "safe house", because the US previously imposed 100% tariffs on Chinese EVs, and now the safe house is no longer safe. The last pillar of the Japanese economy, the automotive industry, will face a very bad future.

In recent years, there have been many sad news in Japan, such as the sharp rise in rice prices, the boom of the prostitution industry, and the prevalence of syphilis. Essentially, this is the result of Japan's previously dominant manufacturing industries such as home appliances, machinery, and shipbuilding being replaced by China. If Japan's automotive industry also declines, Japan's future will be Thailand in Northeast Asia.

Years ago I studied solar data to try to link it to stock price movements. There is a linkage, but it is really hard to use those data in a sensible and reliable way to help make money. Big solar flares, especially X class, are well associated with meaningful turning points.

So I gave up on tracking those data (which was a lot of work). But I still find the phenomenon fascinating.

Canadians are in a state of excitement over Trump tariffs, but the actual deathblow is coming from Carney.

Liberal Prime Minister Mark Carney confirmed last Friday that his government would keep the emissions cap on oil and gas production put in place by the Trudeau government in November 2024. The Cap aims at reducing emissions from the oil and gas sector, including the Newfoundland offshore sector, to 35% below 2019 levels by 2030-2032, 5 years from now.

The NL government and Industry opposed the Cap saying it will result in curtailed production of the Newfoundland and Labrador offshore oil and gas industry. According to Energy NL the oil and gas sector accounts for 25 percent of the province's GDP, over 40% of all exports, and more than eight percent of all provincial employment. Fishing, forestry and mining combined do not come close to matching the importance of the oil and gas industry to the Newfoundland economy.

This issue should be foremost in the minds of all Newfoundlanders and Labradorians when candidates come knocking on their doors in the next few weeks. Trump tariffs are on again, off again, but Carney/Trudeau suppression of our energy sector is a hard core constant, a defining characteristic of Liberal Party of Canada. Carbon fanaticism is an existential threat to the survival of Canada, and a special threat of impoverishment for Alberta and NL.

Here is a list of all Trump Tariffs proposed and confirmed:

1. Canada:
- 25% tariffs on most goods, including steel and aluminum products.
- 10% tariff on oil and gas (delayed until April 2, 2025).
2. Mexico:
- 25% tariffs on all goods.
3. China:
- 20% tariffs on all goods (increased from 10% on March 4, 2025).
4. European Union:
- Planned tariffs on EU goods, with Trump threatening a 200% tariff on EU alcohol.
5. All Countries (Global):
- 25% tariffs on steel and aluminum products, effective March 12, 2025.
- 25% tariffs on all vehicles manufactured outside the U.S., set to commence on April 2, 2025.
6. Russia:
- 200% duty rate on imports of derivative aluminum articles or those using primary aluminum smelted or cast in Russia.
7. Other Countries:
- Reciprocal tariffs planned for April 2, 2025, targeting 15% of nations that account for the majority of U.S. foreign trade.
- Potential targets include India, Thailand, Taiwan, Vietnam, Japan, and Malaysia, based on trade surpluses with the US or differences in average tariff rates.

- Venezuela: Trump announced plans for a "secondary tariff" of 25% on any country purchasing oil or gas from Venezuela when trading with the U.S., effective April 2, 2025.
- Digital Service Taxes (DSTs): Investigation initiated against France, Austria, Italy, Spain, Turkey, and the UK.
- Copper, Timber, and Lumber: Section 232 investigations initiated for potential tariffs.

London Metal Exchange raised the APT notation from 345/370 to 350/370. However, no Chinese tungsten exports occurred since Feb 4th, and no export license under the new regulation has been granted, resulting in no spot business.

The enclosed ARGUS graph shows Rotterdam prices rising, while Chinese APT prices remain significantly lower. As Chinese producers remain uncertain about export timelines, they aren't buying material for export, keeping prices low. Still, some Chinese sources indicated this week that inventories are low, requiring renewed concentrate purchasing soon, which they expect will drive domestic tungsten prices upward.

Since the new export regulations started on Feb 4th, tungsten exports dropped 66% from January to February this year and 47% compared to Feb 2024, according to the Chinese Nonferrous Metals Industry Ass. Conversely, China's tungsten concentrate imports in Jan-Feb rose by 30% year-over-year.

Europe is considering increasing imports of Russian gas amid increasingly tense relations with Trump, writes Der Spiegel. The publication clarifies that the European Union has found itself in an energy trap: in the West, there is Donald Trump, who is trying to impose more liquefied natural gas, and in the East, there is Russia, which insists on the return of the Nord Stream 2 project.

Europe's dual position is best illustrated by what Brussels is not doing. By the end of March, EU Energy Commissioner Dan Jorgensen promised to present a master plan for the EU to completely abandon Russian gas supplies. Tariffs live updates:Â US stocks rebound on soaring Tesla shares ahead of presidentâ€™s announcement

President Trump's plan to impose tariffs on global imports is intended to level the playing field, according to the administration. Hereâ€™s a concise summary of countries placing tariffs on US products.

Argentina: Average tariff rate of 22% (since 2019).

Australia: 10% Goods and Services Tax (GST) on low-value imported goods.

Brazil: Complex taxes including Import Duty, Industrialized Product Tax, Merchandise and Service Circulation tax, and various smaller cumulative taxes.

Canada: Low de minimis threshold (CAD $40 for taxes, CAD $150 for duties), creating barriers especially for online and small-value sales.

China: Average Most-Favored-Nation (MFN) tariff rate of 7.57%, with complex variations by product.

European Union: Average MFN rate of 5.2%; higher on specific goods (26% fish, 22% trucks, 10% vehicles, etc.). Value Added Tax (VAT) of 20% applied uniformly and not considered a tariff.

India: Average tariff of 17%, varies significantly by product.

Indonesia: Tariffs exceeding WTO bound rates, particularly 10% on ICT products, 5% on computer servers.

Japan: Low average MFN tariff rate of 4.3% overall; 15.5% agricultural, 2.5% non-agricultural.

South Korea: 10% VAT on all imports plus 10â€“20% excise tax on luxury/durable goods.

Malaysia: Average tariff of 6.1% for industrial goods, significantly higher for alcohol, wine, poultry, pork; Sales and Services Tax (SST) at 5â€“10%.

Mexico: Generally no tariffs due to USMCA, though specific exceptions may apply.

Russia: Tariffs largely irrelevant currently due to geopolitical factors; trade significantly reduced (90% drop post-2021).

Saudi Arabia: GCC common tariff of at least 5%; higher rates applied selectively on processed food imports.

South Africa: Uniform VAT rate of 15% on nearly all imports.

Switzerland: Low tariffs averaging 1.7%; high agricultural tariffs (average 30.4%, dairy 137.7%).

Taiwan: Average nominal tariff of 6.34% overall (4.13% industrial, 15.06% agricultural).

Thailand: Average MFN tariff 11.5%; higher for agriculture (31.2%) and significantly high tariffs on automobiles, wine (effective burden nearly 400%), textiles, etc.

Turkey: Average 5% MFN tariff on industrial goods; significantly higher tariffs on agricultural and processed goods (up to 70% additional tariff on U.S. spirits/liquors).

United Kingdom: 20% VAT generally, reduced rates (5%) for selected products, 0% on food and children's clothing; duties vary by product.

Vietnam: Most tariffs at 15% or less; recently increasing tariffs selectively on products competing with local production.

This Bloomberg chart shows how the US hasn't seen tariffs this high for nearly a century. I've added a line that tracks US Imports / US GDP, to see how important imports were to the US economy.

Up to 1970, imports were 4-5% of the US economy. The 1973 oil shock crisis raised the cost of oil and among other factors, caused imports to surge as a percentage of GDP. This settled with imports at 13-17% of GDP with oil only around 5% of imports, so non-oil goods are clearly a much bigger factor now. I surmise that an economy could adapt for tariffs slowly changed over 10 years but if these sudden tariffs persist, then it will have profound effects on the world economy.

In the Budget 2025, FM Nirmala Sitharaman had announced a scheme to establish India as a global toy hub through cluster development, focusing on skills and a manufacturing ecosystem for high quality, 'Made in India' toys. This aims to reduce India's reliance on toy imports, particularly from China, which accounted for 76% of imports over the past decade. 

Notably, India's toy imports from China significantly decreased from $214 million in FY13 to $41.6 million in FY24, causing China's share in India's toy imports to drop from 94% to 64%, indicating improved domestic competitiveness.

ğŸš¨ BREAKING: Wedbush has lowered its price target on Tesla $TSLA from $550 to $315:

â€œMusk Created Brand Crisis + Trump Tariffs = Perfect Storm For Tesla..PT to $315

The economic tariff Armageddon unleashed by the Trump Administration is a double whammy for Tesla in our view. Tesla is less exposed to tariffs than other US automakers such as GM, Ford, and Stellantis as well as foreign autos...although Tesla still derives a considerable amount of its parts/batteries from sources outside the US including China. This will be a clear cost impact to Tesla in the US and ultimately be passed on to consumers with some demand destruction if these tariffs hold in their current form. The tariffs in their current form will disrupt Tesla, the overall supply chain, and its global footprint which has been a clear advantage over the years vs. rising competitors like BYD.
The bigger worry in our opinion is Tesla's success in China as this key region is the linchpin to the future success of Tesla. The backlash from Trump tariff policies in China and Musk's association will be hard to understate and this will further drive Chinese consumers to buy domestic such as BYD, Nio, Xpeng, and others. Tesla has essentially become a political symbol globally....and that is a very bad thing for the future of this disruptive tech stalwart and the brand crisis tornado that has now turned into an F5 tornado. We now estimate Tesla has lost/destroyed at least 10% of its future customer base globally based on self created brand issues and this could be a conservative estimate. In Europe, this number could be 20% or higher....all self-inflicted by Musk.
Tesla has unfortunately become a political symbol because of Musk and this is a very bad thing for the future of this technology stalwart. With major protests erupting globally at Tesla dealerships, Tesla cars being keyed, and a full brand crisis tornado turning into a life of its own this has cast a dark black cloud over Tesla's stock. The future is so bright for Tesla with Austin's unsupervised FSD, lower-cost vehicles, and of course the autonomous and robotics future....but this is a full blown crisis Tesla is navigating now (along with these tariffs), and it is time for Musk to step up, read the room, and be a leader in this time of uncertainty.
For the stock, the demand destruction for Tesla and brand damage is real and has morphed into something much more concerning over the past few months. The 1Q delivery number was a disaster as we discussed last week but this could be a brutal year ahead if Musk does not exit stage left or take a step back on DOGE in the coming month. We are taking a stab at new reduced estimates for 2025/2026 which could be a moving target with the tariffs, retaliatory, and the China wild card.
Our long standing bull view of Tesla remains, but there is no denying this is a pivotal moment of truth for Musk to turn things around...or darker days are ahead. We have been one of the biggest supporters of Musk and Tesla over the last decade....but this situation is not sustainable and the brand of Tesla is suffering by the day as a political symbol. Musk has been with his back against the wall many times and every time Tesla came out of it and was stronger on the other side...this may be one of his biggest challenges yet to turn around. We are lowering our price target from $550 to $315 to reflect these new softer demand estimates. We maintain our OUTPERFORM rating.â€
