ğŸ”¥WHAT YOU NEED TO KNOW about CRUDE OILğŸ›¢ï¸
We always recover from these shocks in crude oil, but it takes time, and this is just the start. Remember, the world economy runs on crude oil, every market is affected by this decline.
Youâ€™ll know I trade crude oil. Hereâ€™s a look at history that may shed light on whatâ€™s in the future. Almost every time oil collapses by 7% or more, itâ€™s either:
ğŸš©A supply shock (too much oil, not enough cuts),
ğŸš©A demand shock (pandemics, recessions, tariffs),
ğŸš©Or a macro panic (financial crashes, credit 
        downgrades).
This week saw oil prices tank more than 10% as President Donald Trumpâ€™s tariffs went into effect. A single-day drop of more than 7% in global oil prices is rare but not unheard of. It usually signals something dramatic. the spectre of war (directly involving the U.S.), pandemics, or, in this case, a brewing global trade war.

We have been here before, and not that long ago. In fact, Here are six incidents/events that led to single-day oil price crashes of >7% just since mid-2020.

ğŸš©August 1, 2019 â€“ Trumpâ€™s Tariff Threat (-7.9%)
WTI: -7.9% | Brent: -7.0%
President Trump had tweeted out a new 10% tariff on $300 billion of Chinese imports, cratering oil prices as the markets panicked over trade war escalation and a global demand slowdown. 

ğŸš©March 9, 2020 â€“ The Price War Meltdown (-24.6%)
This was the granddaddy of all plunges. After OPEC+ talks fell apart, Saudi Arabia and Russia launched an oil price war just as the COVID-19 pandemic was going global. Crude fell, hard. WTI crashed 24.6% in a single day, marking the second-largest one-day percentage drop in history.

ğŸš©April 20, 2020 â€“ Below Zero (-305%)ğŸ‘ˆ
WTI: From $18.27 to -$37.63 Brent: $25
Just over a month later, global oil markets felt the sting of yet another drop. This was the largest drop in absolute dollar terms in history. WTI literally went negative. This is the now-infamous day crude prices crashed through zero and hit minus $37.63 per barrel for a more than 300% drop. 

The fiasco was exacerbated because the trading software wasnâ€™t set up to handle negative prices there simply wasnâ€™t the capacity to display or execute negative prices. Some systems auto-liquidated positions or froze trading. Sellers were stuck. The initial catalyst, however, were storage tanks that were full, and no one wanted physical delivery in May. The result? The oil market went full Twilight Zone. Brent didnâ€™t go negative (itâ€™s a seaborne crude), but WTIâ€™s drop that day rewrote the rules.

ğŸš©November 26, 2021 â€“ The Omicron Drop (-13.1%)
WTI: -13.1% | Brent: -11.6%
Black Friday 2021 was brutal for oil. News of the new Omicron COVID variant spooked markets, and oil took the brunt. Traders feared more travel bans, lockdowns, and demand destruction. WTI lost over 13% on the day, one of its steepest pandemic-era declines

ğŸš©July 19, 2021- OPEC+ Strikes Output Deal (-7.5%)
WTI: -7.5% | Brent: -6.8%
OPEC+ agreed to boost production by 400,000 bpd. While this eased lingering supply concerns, it was perhaps too much easing and the market interpreted this as too much, too soonâ€”especially with Delta Covid variant headlines spooking demand outlooks.
April 3, 2025 â€“ Tariffs and OPEC Firebomb (-7%)

ğŸš©WTI: -7% | Brent: -6.4%
President Trumpâ€™s latest tariff announcement blitzed markets with Liberation Tariffs just as OPEC+ surprised with a 411,000 bpd production hike for May. Prices cratered, with WTI sinking 7% and Brent close behind. The two macro punches on the same day resulted in a case of textbook chaos.

$NIO ğŸ’ğŸ™ŒğŸ»

Tariffs are affecting NIO, the Chinese electric vehicle (EV) company, in a largely indirect manner as of April 08, 2025, given that NIO does not currently export vehicles to the U.S., where some of the most significant tariff increases on Chinese EVs have been implemented. However, the broader implications of tariffsâ€”particularly those imposed by the U.S. and the European Union (EU)â€”still create ripple effects that influence NIOâ€™s operations, market sentiment, and strategic decisions.

The U.S. imposed a 100% tariff on Chinese-made EVs in May 2024 under the Biden administration, effectively quadrupling the previous 25% rate. This move was designed to protect domestic automakers and counter perceived unfair subsidies from the Chinese government. Since NIO does not sell vehicles in the U.S. market yet (though it has expressed interest in entering North America by 2025), these tariffs do not directly impact its current sales. However, they limit NIOâ€™s potential future expansion into the U.S., as the high tariff wall makes it economically unfeasible to export vehicles from China without significant price hikes that would erode competitiveness against domestic players like Tesla, Rivian, or Ford.

In the EU, tariffs on Chinese EVs were finalized in October 2024, ranging from 17.4% to 37.6% on top of the existing 10% import duty, following an investigation into Chinese subsidies. NIO, identified as a cooperating company, faces a 21% additional duty. While NIO has begun selling vehicles in Europe (e.g., the EL8/ES8 deliveries started in September 2024), its European sales volume remains small compared to its primary market in China. The company has maintained current prices for now but has warned that price adjustments may be necessary if definitive measures are enforced. This could reduce NIOâ€™s competitiveness in Europe against local brands or other Chinese EV makers like BYD (which faces a lower 17.4% tariff) or Tesla (with a 7.8% rate due to its Shanghai factory). NIOâ€™s commitment to the European market remains firm, but the tariffs force it to weigh options like local manufacturing partnershipsâ€”something it has hinted at exploringâ€”to mitigate costs.

In China, where NIO delivers the vast majority of its vehicles (e.g., 13,863 in February 2025 alone), tariffs abroad can indirectly affect the company through economic and trade dynamics. If U.S. and EU tariffs escalate into a broader trade war, Chinaâ€™s economy could face pressure from reduced exports in other sectors, potentially softening consumer spending on premium EVs like NIOâ€™s. Additionally, China might retaliate with tariffs on foreign automakers like Tesla, which exports from Shanghai to Europe and elsewhere. This could benefit NIO domestically by making Teslaâ€™s offerings less competitive in China, where Tesla is a key rival. Some X posts suggest this scenario could be a â€œwin-winâ€ for NIO, as it faces no direct U.S. tariff hit and could gain from reduced foreign competition at home.

Investor sentiment toward NIOâ€™s U.S.-listed stock ($NIO) is another indirect casualty of tariff tensions. Trade disputes often spook markets, leading to sell-offs in Chinese ADRs (American Depositary Receipts) like NIOâ€™s, even if the companyâ€™s fundamentals remain solid. Posts on X from early April 2025 highlight this volatility, noting NIOâ€™s stock dropping amid tariff news despite its lack of U.S. sales, attributing it to broader economic uncertainty or â€œtariff tides affecting all ships.â€ NIOâ€™s valuationâ€”around 0.7x projected 2025 revenuesâ€”reflects this cautious sentiment, though it remains attractive compared to Teslaâ€™s 9x multiple.

A lesson for Trump and Russia about unintended consequences...

While Trump's love for Putin meant no direct tariffs, global "tariff wars", nervous markets, and a potential global economic downturn severely impact oil prices.

For Russia, every $1 decline in the price of a barrel of oil annually reduces export revenues by about $2.7bn. 

A drop from $82 per barrel in January to $62 today, if sustained, means on an annualised basis, Russia will lose over $54bn in oil revenues.

A global economic downturn and OPEC's plan to increase supply could easily push Brent crude to $55 or even $50 a barrel by 2026 (according to Goldman Sachs), creating a $73bn or $86.4bn economic shortfall for Russia compared to early 2025.  

The notion that Russia has escaped the tariff war is laughable. Good luck funding your tyrannical, despotic war machine, you bastards.

Wind Financial Morning Post: April 10, 2025

China has adjusted tariffs on imported goods from the United States, raising rates significantly, reflecting ongoing trade disputes. Additionally, the Chinese government released a white paper addressing various issues regarding Sino-American economic and trade relations. The report underscores China's commitment to open trade principles and highlights areas where the United States has violated agreements under WTO rules.

The State Council Tariff Commission issued a bulletin announcing higher tariffs on U.S. imports effective from April 10, 12:01 PM. The tariff rate will rise from 34% to 84% on all goods originating from the United States. In a related move, the Ministry of Commerce highlighted that America's tariffs measures severely violate WTO rules and emphasized China's commitment to defending its legitimate interests and maintaining multilateral trade system norms.

In addition, the State Council Information Office published a comprehensive white paper titled â€œChina's Position on Issues Concerning China-U.S. Economic and Trade Relations.â€ The document clarifies the mutual benefit inherent in economic ties between the two nations, addresses obligations under Phase 1 of their trade agreement, and outlines China's adherence to free trade principles and WTO practices, affirming its willingness to engage in equitable dialogue to resolve trade disputes.

Following recent trends, a significant inflow into A- share ETF products totaling more than 190 billion yuan over April 7-8 has reinforced market stability. Concurrently, multiple Chinese state entities announced stock buybacks and shareholder investment to bolster listed companiesâ€™ market valuations.

This week, more than 100 A-share companies announced buyback or shareholder increase plans, with a staggering commitment exceeding 10 billion yuan, further signaling robust investor confidence. Notable institutional investors, along with domestic private equity giants, continued reallocating investments into sectors such as semiconductors, artificial intelligence, and new-energy vehicles despite escalated market volatility.

Brokerage firms have also started releasing buyback plans. As of April 9, at least seven companies in the financial sector issued proposals supporting capital stability through repurchased shares. Investment-related actions also extended into agriculture, with CITIC Group boosting its stake in leading agricultural firm Longping Hi-Tech in a 12 billion yuan funding round.

Shifting to market performance, China's A-share indices saw robust gains amid high trading activity. On April 9, 2025, the SSE Index rose by 1.31%, the Shenzhen Component Index increased by 1.22%, and the ChiNext Index gained 0.98%. Furthermore, the Star 50 and BSE 50 Index skyrocketed by 4.31% and 10.27%, respectively, as over 4,500 stocks advanced and around 130 stocks hit the daily limit-up. The total market turnover reached an impressive 1.74 trillion yuan(approximately 267 billion USD).

In the bond market, government bond futures closed slightly higher, demonstrating strength in fixed-income assets. Interbank rates saw a slight reduction, including overnight and seven-day repo rates weighted averages. Traders observed that the PBOC alternated between net injection and net withdrawal of funds through reverse repo operations, aiming to maintain market liquidity without excessively easing monetary conditions.

Â -----BEGIN TEARLINE-----

-HomeFront-

New York: This afternoon a private helicopter (tail number: N216MH) crashed in the Hudson River in the vicinity of the Holland Tunnel. As of this report, no survivors have been reported, though rescue operations are ongoing.

North Dakota: Tuesday morning a rupture was reported at the Keystone pipeline near Fort Ransom. Roughly 3,500 barrels of oil were spilled in a farmer's field as a result of the pipeline rupture.

Kentucky: Recovery efforts continue following the flooding events of the past week. Severe weather events swept through the region last week, causing widespread damage from the floods. Many areas are still inaccessible due to roads washing out, and debris generally causing challenges with transportation.

Washington D.C. - Tariff shenanigans continue as the White House clarifies the math on the total tariffs on China. So far, the final tally as of this morning is that a 145% tariff on all imports from China is in effect.

-----END TEARLINE-----

Analyst Comments: As the helicopter crash in New York is a developing situation, not much is confirmed. Eyewitnesses state that the aircraft broke up mid-flight, with no obvious signs of distress or mechanical failure before the incident. Analysis of the aircraft's transponder data does not indicate any abnormal flight pattern before the incident that may indicate what happened. 

Of note, misleading videos are already circulating on social media, being pushed by very big accounts. An older video of a similar helicopter showing erratic flight is being falsely claimed to be from this incident, when in reality that footage was from a few years ago. In today's age, misleading, old, or even outright fake video clips always circulate on social media in the minutes after a disaster. Despite this, most people on social media quickly forget the accounts that push fake information, thus continuing the circus the next time something happens.

In North Dakota, no cause was reported for the Keystone pipeline incident. However, the impacts will continue to be felt as the pipeline remains shut down (almost three days after the incident) while repairs are underway. This pipeline transports on average 600,000 barrels of crude oil per day, so any downtime whatsoever will probably negatively impact the prices of petroleum products while repairs continue.

Regarding tariffs, the economic stakes are massive. The U.S. and China trade about $700 billion worth of goods annually, including key exports like smartphones, laptops, soybeans, and gas turbines. Without a deal to de-escalate tensions, higher tariffs will likely disrupt supply chains, raise consumer prices, and strain already fragile global markets.
Â 
This will be the first real increase in tariffs under the current monetary regime, and the first major departure of the United States from neo-liberal trade policy to mercantilism in most of our lifetimes. The last material increase in US tariffs was with the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act in 1930, and at that time the US dollar was on the gold standard and Keynes had yet to publish his General Theory.
Â 
Global trade as % of GDP has been steadily rising for decades as most trade barriers have fallen, bringing the broad global gains from trade between countries with differing specializations, but at the cost of self-sufficiency, the focus of the current administration. Sheltering national industries, either through tariffs or capital controls, is not an uncommon strategy in developing countries, but with varying results: broad success in Chinaâ€™s case and numerous failures in Latin America. It is a less common strategy from a leading developed country and is broadly a sign of weakness, not strength.
Â 
If the USâ€™ industries were competitive or innovative enough, they wouldnâ€™t need the governmentâ€™s help to keep them on their feet. This is not to brush aside criticism of other countriesâ€™ unfair policies that put the United States at a disadvantage, such as China dumping solar panels on the US, but we have broadly abandoned the global rules-based infrastructure we helped build to resolve them in an ordered way, in favor of blanket tariffs and bilateral diplomacy.
Â 
Furthermore, trade imbalances are a direct result of the Triffin Dilemma, a concept identified in the 1960s by economist Robbert Triffin, which postulates that the country with the global reserve currency must become a net-exporter of their national currency, naturally resulting in a trade deficit. Imposing tariffs on exporters to the United States, who themselves â€œbuyâ€ dollars when they sell goods to us, makes it harder to export dollars and thus could jeopardize the global reserve status of the U.S. dollar. Stablecoins can be a powerful countervailing force here, which Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent acknowledged at the March 7 crypto roundtable at the White House, in which he said â€œwe are going to keep the U.S. the dominant reserve currency in the world and we are going to use stablecoins to do that.â€ While tariffs and mercantilism may reduce dollar demand from foreign governments or sovereigns, stablecoins can be a force to put dollars directly in the hands of global citizens. Can the White House outsmart the Triffin Dilemma? It seems they plan to try.

There's a loophole (of sorts) in tariffs referred to as "transshipment."

In short what this means is - A company can ship their products to an intermediary country, who then ships the products from there to the actually desired location, with the objective of bypassing tariffs on the country of true origin.

This can be taken a step further - Theoretically, new countries can be "made" simply to circumnavigate tariffs (done through secession/partition). Yes tariffs would be placed on these new countries, but likewise, they could just create new countries faster than legislation can go into place. We see something similar with regulation around THC, where new strains were "created" to bypass regulations.

Would need to do a bit more research, but @grok shared this practices could bypass tariffs, but things do get a bit tricky.

Other loopholes would be in final assembly. Often times there are many products labeled as "Made in USA" that are actually manufactured overseas, but final bolts give it this title. Wise companies should be searching for some level of loopholes in the interim of building factories in the US.

Either companies will absorb the impact, or they will pass it onto customers, with 60% of Americans living paycheck to paycheck, and 80% of Americans in some form of consumer debt... it's gonna hurt.

IRAQI OIL MINISTER EXPECTS PRODUCTIVE MEETING SATURDAY WITH KURDISTAN REGION ON OIL EXPORTS

ğŸ’¥ implementation of the budget law
ğŸ’¥ optimism for reaching an understanding
ğŸ’¥ This round will be productive in signing an agreement and resuming oil exports through the Iraq-Turkey pipeline
ğŸ’¥ deal would lead to the fair distribution of oil revenues among all Iraqis

A delegation from the Kurdistan Region is scheduled to visit Baghdad on Saturday to resume discussions on the long-standing oil export dispute.

The two sides have engaged in multiple rounds of negotiations over the past two years. In February, amendments to the federal budget law provided a legal basis for resuming oil exports. However, disagreements have so far delayed the process.

Iraqi Oil Minister Hayan Abdul Ghani told Channel8 that there is optimism for reaching an understanding with the Kurdistan Region. â€œThere are negotiations with the brothers in the Kurdistan Region on the implementation of the budget law. Several rounds have already been held, and the next will take place this Saturday,â€ he said.

He expressed confidence that this round would lead to tangible results. â€œThis round will be productive in signing an agreement and resuming oil exports through the Iraq-Turkey pipeline. For context, the halt in exports has caused significant damage to Iraq. Since oil production from the Kurdistan Region is counted within Iraqâ€™s OPEC quota, we have been compensating by cutting production in the southern fields,â€ he added.

Abdul Ghani also voiced hope that a deal would lead to the fair distribution of oil revenues among all Iraqis.

Despite the suspension of exports for more than two years, the Kurdistan Region continues to produce around 300,000 barrels of oil per day, according to the minister.

Meanwhile, Kurdistan Region Prime Minister Masrour Barzani told Channel8 that Erbil has fulfilled its responsibilities and is now waiting for Baghdad to reach an agreement with the oil companies.

In 2022, Iraqâ€™s Federal Court annulled the Kurdistan Regionâ€™s Oil and Gas Law. On March 25, 2023, exports from the Kurdistan Region to the Turkish port of Ceyhan were officially halted.

Officials from the Kurdistan Region estimate the financial losses from the suspension of exports to exceed $23 billion. 

The key obstacles to resuming exports include settling debts owed to oil companies and securing future financial guaranteesâ€”issues expected to be on the table during Saturdayâ€™s talks in Baghdad.

SULAIMANI, Kurdistan Region â€” A planned tripartite meeting involving the Kurdistan Regionâ€™s Ministry of Natural Resources, international oil companies, and Iraqâ€™s Oil Ministry to discuss the long-awaited resumption of oil exports has been postponed, Zoom News has learned.

China stops buying liquefied natural gas from the US | Malcolm Moore, Financial Times

Standstill shows how Sino-American trade war has spilled into the energy sector

Chinaâ€™s imports of US liquefied natural gas have completely stopped for more than 10 weeks, according to shipping data showing how the Sino-American trade war has spread to energy co-operation.

Since a 69,000-tonne LNG tanker from Corpus Christi in Texas arrived in the southern province of Fujian on February 6 there have been no further shipments between the two countries.

A second tanker was redirected to Bangladesh after it failed to arrive before China imposed a 15 per cent tariff on US LNG on February 10. The tariff has since increased to 49 per cent, making US natural gas uneconomic for Chinese buyers for the foreseeable future.

The freeze on US LNG is a repeat of a block on imports that lasted for more than a year during Donald Trumpâ€™s first term as president.

But the impact of the stand-off has potentially far-reaching implications, strengthening Chinaâ€™s energy relationship with Russia and raising questions over the huge expansion of multibillion-dollar LNG terminals that is under way in the US and Mexico.

â€œThere will be long-term consequences,â€ said Anne-Sophie Corbeau, a natural gas specialist at Columbia Universityâ€™s Center on Global Energy Policy. â€œI do not think Chinese LNG importers will ever contract any new US LNG.â€

Since Russiaâ€™s full-scale invasion of Ukraine in 2022, China has imported a relatively low share of its LNG from the US, with Chinese buyers preferring to resell the fuel into Europe for a profit. Last year, only 6 per cent of Chinaâ€™s LNG came from the US, down from a peak of 11 per cent in 2021.

However, Chinese companies including PetroChina and Sinopec have signed 13 long-term contracts to buy LNG from US terminals, some of which run to 2049, according to data from Kpler.

Such long-term deals were essential for getting huge LNG projects off the ground in the US, though Corbeau said developers have recently tried to renegotiate terms to take into consideration rising inflation and the costs from US tariffs.

Gillian Boccara, an analyst at Kpler, said she saw no reason for trade between the two countries to restart in the short term.

â€œThe last time this happened, there was a complete hiatus until the Chinese authorities granted waivers to companies, but that was at a time when gas demand was booming,â€ she said. â€œNow we are looking at lower economic growth, and we think the Chinese can withstand the loss of these cargoes for quite a long time.â€

Chinaâ€™s ambassador to Russia said earlier this week that China would probably step up its imports of Russian LNG instead. â€œI know for sure that there are a lot of buyers. So many buyers are asking the embassy to help establish contacts with Russian suppliers, I think there will definitely be more [imports],â€ said Zhang Hanhui.

ERBIL (Kurdistan24) â€” A trilateral meeting was convened in Erbil on Sunday among representatives of the Iraqi Ministry of Oil, Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG), and the Association of the Petroleum Industry of Kurdistan (APIKUR) to address critical issues concerning the Kurdistan Region's oil sector, with a primary focus on resuming oil exports. Omid Sabah, Chief of Staff of the KRG Council of Ministers, stated that discussions involved the operational activities of oil companies and explored mechanisms to facilitate the restart of exports.Â The meeting also considered the challenges and proposals presented by these companies to create a conducive environment for resuming oil exports promptly.

Despite the Iraqi Parliament's approval of amendments to the federal budget law on February 2, 2025, particularly Article 12 concerning the resumption of Kurdistan's oil exports, disagreements between the federal government and the KRG have hindered the implementation of these provisions. The amendments stipulate that the federal Ministry of Finance will compensate the KRG for production and transportation costs of oil delivered to the State Oil Marketing Organization (SOMO).Â An international technical advisory body, to be appointed jointly by the federal and regional governments, was tasked with determining the fair cost of production and transportation for each oil field within 60 days of the law's enactment. However, this deadline has passed without an agreement, prompting concerns from Iraqi lawmakers.

Adnan al-Jaberi, Deputy Chairman of the Iraqi Parliament's Oil and Gas Committee, emphasized that the 60-day period to select a consulting firm has expired without consensus. He noted that, in the absence of agreement, the federal government reserves the right to unilaterally appoint the advisory body.

Meanwhile, oil production companies operating in the Kurdistan Region have expressed skepticism toward the Iraqi Ministry of Oil. These companies demand the settlement of outstanding payments for past production, advance payments, and future guarantees as prerequisites for resuming export operations.

The halt in oil exports since March 2023, following a ruling by the International Chamber of Commerce in Paris, has significantly impacted the Kurdistan Region's economy, leading to delays in public sector salaries and reductions in essential services. Baghdad is under increasing pressure to resolve these disputes to restore financial stability and economic growth across Iraq.

As negotiations continue, the resumption of oil exports remains contingent upon resolving contractual disagreements, ensuring fair compensation for production and transportation costs, and rebuilding trust between the federal government and oil companies operating in the region.

The port of Bandar Abbas in Iran is a significant hub for oil exports, handling a substantial portion of the country's seaborne trade. According to the latest data, Bandar Abbas is Iran's main fuel oil export terminal and plays a crucial role in the country's oil industry.

Oil Export Volumes
â€¢Recent Export Data: According to the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA), Iran exported an average of 1.4 million barrels per day of crude oil and condensate in 2023, rising to approximately 1.5 million barrels per day during the first eight months of 2024.While this data does not specify the exact volume exported through Bandar Abbas, it is a significant contributor to Iran's total oil exports.

â€¢Port Capacity: Bandar Abbas handles a substantial portion of Iran's oil exports, particularly fuel oil. The port's capacity and infrastructure are designed to support large-scale oil shipments, making it a vital component of Iran's energy sector.
Historical Context and Recent Developments

â€¢Economic and Political Significance: The petroleum industry is a cornerstone of Iran's economy, accounting for a significant portion of the country's foreign currency earnings. In 2004, Iran produced 5.1% of the world's total crude oil, generating revenues of US$25 billion to US$30 billion. The oil and gas sector has been the primary driver of economic growth, directly affecting public development projects, the government's annual budget, and foreign exchange sources.

â€¢Recent Incidents: On April 26, 2025, a massive explosion occurred at the Shahid Rajaee section of the Bandar Abbas port, killing at least 28 people and injuring over 800 others. The National Iranian Oil Refining and Distribution Company (NIORDC) stated that the explosion was not related to refineries, fuel tanks, or oil pipelines associated with the company in that area. 

The incident has raised concerns about the safety and security of Iran's critical infrastructure, particularly in light of ongoing negotiations with the United States over Iran's nuclear program.

ERBIL, Kurdistan Region - The Kurdistan Regionâ€™s Council of Ministers said on Wednesday that it has met its obligations for resuming the Regionâ€™s oil exports, calling on the relevant authorities in Erbil and Baghdad to restart the process â€œas soon as possible.â€
The Council of Ministers held its weekly meeting in Erbil on Wednesday to discuss a range of issues, particularly the Kurdish oil exports which have been suspended for over two years.Â 
â€œThe Council of Ministers reaffirms its unchanging position in support of negotiations and discussions between both the Oil Ministry and Natural Resources Ministry for the soonest possible resumption of oil exports,â€ read a statement from the Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG).Â  Â 
â€œTo this end, the Council of Ministers calls on the [Kurdish] Ministry of Natural Resources, the Federal Oil Ministry, oil companies, and [Iraqâ€™s State Oil Marketing Organization] SOMO to continue coordination and negotiation in order to resolve the issues and reach an agreement as soon as possible to resume Kurdistan Region's oil exports and to prevent further financial losses to the general treasury, which have already exceeded tens of billions of dollars,â€ it added.Â 
Oil exports from the Kurdistan Region through the Iraq-Turkey pipeline have been suspended since March 2023, after a Paris-based arbitration court ruled in favor of Baghdad, stating that Ankara had violated a 1973 pipeline agreement by allowing Erbil to export oil independently.
Iraqâ€™s foreign ministerÂ saidÂ on Tuesday that Baghdad is seeking to resume Kurdish oil exports through the Iraq-Turkey pipeline and will â€œmake every effortâ€ to do so.
Myles Caggins, spokesperson for the Association of the Petroleum Industry of Kurdistan (APIKUR), an umbrella group of international oil companies operating in the Kurdistan Region,Â toldÂ Rudaw on Tuesday that Baghdad must provide written documentation of the international consultantâ€™s audit of production and costs.
"I want to make APIKURâ€™s position clear. Our companies are ready to resume oil exports when we have agreements, and we need agreements for sales and also an agreement for the international consultant that is required by Iraq's budget law," he added.Â 
In early February, the Iraqi parliament approved amendments to the federal budget law, authorizing a $16-per-barrel fee for production and transport costs in the Kurdistan Region - a move seen as a crucial step toward restarting exports.
The amendments also require both the federal government and the KRG to establish an international technical consultancy within 60 days to assess production and transportation costs for oil fields in the Kurdistan Region. If an agreement cannot be reached, the federal council of ministers will appoint the consultancy.

U.S. Imposes Sweeping Tariffs on Southeast Asian Solar Panels, Drawing Concern from ASEAN+3

The United States has introduced a new wave of steep tariffs on solar panel imports from Southeast Asia, in a move that is deepening trade tensions and triggering alarm across the Asia-Pacific region. The tariffs - ranging from 34% to a staggering 3,521% -target producers in Cambodia, Malaysia, Thailand, and Vietnam, following a year-long investigation prompted by U.S. manufacturersâ€™ complaints of market distortion through cheap, Chinese-subsidized solar components.

Announced by the U.S. Department of Commerce, the tariffs include both general and company-specific rates: 34.41% on Malaysian panels, 375.2% for a producer from Thailand, and 395.9% for Vietnam. Cambodia was hit particularly hard, with general tariffs of 651.85%. Two companiesâ€”Hounen Solar and Solar Long PV-Techâ€”face extraordinary rates as high as 3,521%, effectively pricing them out of the U.S. market. These duties come on top of the existing 10% tariff on most imports and any reciprocal tariffs already in place.

The targeted companies represent about 77% of solar module imports into the U.S., according to Bloomberg. Analysts warn that other nations, including Indonesia, India, and Laos, may face similar measures later this year, as Washington intensifies scrutiny of its green technology supply chains.

The move has sparked concern across Asia, particularly among Southeast Asian economies. During the Asian Development Bankâ€™s annual meeting in Milan, finance ministers and central bank governors from ASEAN and its dialogue partners - China, Japan, and South Korea (collectively ASEAN+3) - issued a carefully worded but pointed statement.

â€œEscalating trade protectionism weighs on global trade, leading to economic fragmentation, affecting trade, investment and capital flows across the region,â€ the ASEAN+3 officials said in their joint communiquÃ©. The statement did not name the United States directly, it reaffirmed the blocâ€™s commitment to â€œa rules-based, free, fair and transparent multilateral trading system.â€

As the global economy becomes increasingly fractured along geopolitical lines, the latest U.S. tariffs highlight the growing challenges faced by middle-power economies caught between strategic competition and supply chain realignment. The ASEAN+3 response signals a broader unease over unilateral protectionist measures and a desire to uphold stability through international cooperation and open markets.

@grok: The only concrete example of a country attempting to back a currency with oil is Venezuelaâ€™s $Petro, launched in 2018. While the Petro was claimed to be backed by Venezuelaâ€™s oil reserves (one Petro = one barrel of oil), its implementation was ineffective due to a lack of transparency, limited adoption, and eventual abandonment by 2024. No other country has successfully backed a currency with oil in the formal sense, though oil-rich nations often rely on oil revenues to support their currencies indirectly (e.g., Saudi Riyal, Kuwaiti Dinar).

Answer: Yes, Venezuela attempted to back a currency with oil through the Petro, launched in February 2018. The Petro was claimed to be backed by Venezuelaâ€™s oil and mineral reserves, with each unit tied to the value of one barrel of oil. However, the initiative largely failed due to a lack of transparency, limited adoption, and its eventual abandonment by 2024. No other country has successfully backed a currency with oil, though oil revenues often support the economies of petrocurrency nations like Saudi Arabia and Kuwait.

Wind Financial Morning Post: May 7, 2025

China's financial markets opened on a positive note, with high-level Sino-US trade talks drawing significant attention. Chinese Vice Premier He Lifeng is set to meet U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen during his visit to Switzerland. The Ministry of Commerce stated that China has agreed to engage in dialogues with the U.S. Meanwhile, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs emphasized the necessity for the U.S. to stop exerting pressure tactics.

Yellen expressed optimism over potential progress in trade negotiations in the coming weeks and remarked on the unsustainable nature of the 145% tariffs imposed on Chinese goods during the Trump administration. Additionally, Chinese A-share listed companies reported robust first-quarter results, with 75.46% achieving profitabilityâ€”showcasing the resilience of China's economy.

On the domestic macroeconomic front, Finance Minister Lan Fo'an highlighted that China is committed to proactive macroeconomic policies to meet its 2025 growth target of approximately 5%. However, the Caixin China Services PMI in April fell to a seven-month low, signaling a slowdown in business expansion. Data from the State Taxation Administration revealed accelerated investment in engineering projects in the first quarter, and the May Day holiday saw domestic tourists' total spending, grow by 6.4% year-on-year, with 314 million domestic tourism tripsâ€”a 6.4% increase compared to the previous year.

In financial policy updates, the State Council's Information Office announced a forthcoming press conference to outline a comprehensive financial policy package aimed at stabilizing market expectations. Vice Governor of the PBOC, Xuan Changneng, stated that the country is advancing legislation on deposit insurance law to strengthen its core deposit insurance functions.

In domestic economic developments, first-quarter earnings of A-share listed companies reflected a strong start, with 75.46% of enterprises reporting profits, underscoring the country's economic momentum. This aligns with China's 2025 GDP growth target of around 5%, as reiterated by Minister of Finance Liu Kun, who also pledged to further open China's economy to the global market.

A-share markets saw significant upward momentum on the first trading day after the May Day holiday. The SSE Index rose 1.13%, closing at 3,395 points, while the Shenzhen Component Index gained 1.84%, and the ChiNext Index advanced 1.97%. The broader Wind All China Index surged by 1.62%. Total market turnover expanded to 1.36 trillion yuan, with nearly 5,000 stocks seeing gains. Chinese bond markets were also active, though the main treasury bond futures contracts saw mixed movements: the 10-year bond futures declined by 0.16%, while the 5-year bond futures slipped 0.09%.

ğŸ“ˆ The Evolution of Saudi Arabiaâ€™s Trade with China, the EU, and the U.S.

China has emerged as Saudi Arabiaâ€™s largest trading partner and the worldâ€™s leading importer of crude oil, while Saudi Arabia stands as Chinaâ€™s primary trade partner in the Middle East and its second-largest global crude oil supplier. In 2024, bilateral trade between the two countries reached $107 billionâ€”surpassing Saudi Arabiaâ€™s combined trade with the European Union ($75 billion) and the United States ($26 billion). This shift underscores a broader realignment of Saudi Arabiaâ€™s economic ties toward Asia, particularly in the context of Chinaâ€™s growing influence in global energy markets.

From 2000 to 2024, Saudi-China trade expanded at a remarkable 15.9% compound annual growth rate (CAGR), soaring from just $3.1 billion to $107 billion. Over the same period, trade with the EU grew at a 4.5% CAGR (from $26 billion to $75 billion), while trade with the U.S. increased at a modest 1.0% CAGR (from $21 billion to $26 billion). These figures highlight Chinaâ€™s rapidly rising share in Saudi Arabiaâ€™s global trade portfolio.

Timmerman believes that President Trump could favor Erbil over Baghdad in future disputesâ€”especially in matters of oil exports and regional influence. â€œif I were to make a guess, I would say that president Trump would come out on the side of Erbil over Baghdad [...] Right now, Baghdad is being, has been infiltrated for years and years by Tehran, by the Iranian regime, so that's going to be the point of conflict.â€

He cited efforts to reopen the Ceyhan pipeline for Kurdish oil exports to Europe via Turkey as a test case for U.S.-Kurdish cooperation. â€œ[Prime Minister] Barzani has very good relations with the Turkish government, and that will help. And President Trump has very good personal relationships with President Erdogan. So I think that's the way that they would both like to go [...] but then they would have to get the agreement of Baghdad.â€

The broader vision Timmerman laid out involves integrating the Kurdistan Region into a regional defense network against Iranian expansionism. While he acknowledged political constraints due to Iraq's federal structure, he stressed that long-term U.S. interests lie in seeing a unified, professional Peshmerga army and a Kurdish government that can contribute to collective regional security.

â€œI think the United States would like to see the Peshmerga as a united force, as a single force, not as party militias, but as a single government force, to express the will of the KRG government as a whole,â€ he said.

â€œI think also, they would like to see a, you know, a global or I should say a regional, air defense system. I'm not sure that they're ready yet to bring Kurdistan into that because of the relationship with Baghdad. Again, Baghdad is infiltrated by the Iranian regime, and that is a severe problem. But I think, ultimately, that would be the goal to see, the KRG as part of a regional alliance to defend the interests of freedom-loving countries against the Iranian regime,â€ he added.

Asked whether the Kurdistan Region could realistically seal its borders from Iranian infiltration, Timmerman responded with guarded optimism: â€œI hope your Prime Minister will ask for assistance from Washington to help seal the borders with Iran, so the Iranians can no longer infiltrate, can penetrate, and can do damage to, your citizens, inside the Kurdish region.â€

Timmerman emphasized that peace and stability in Kurdistan are not merely regional concerns but strategic priorities for the United States. He noted that the Kurdish Region, as part of Iraq, is demonstrating that a moderate, non-radical, pro-Western polity can exist in the Middle East, adding that it is in America's interest to ensure that this continues.

For Kenneth R. Timmerman, the choice is clear: reinforce the U.S.-Kurdistan alliance, resist Iranian encroachment, and build an enduring partnership grounded in security, sovereignty, and shared prosperity.

ğŸ“ˆ EU Crude Oil Imports: Major Shifts Post-Russia Sanctions (2021â€“2024)

EU sanctions on Russia, triggered by the 2022 Ukraine invasion, slashed EU crude oil imports from Russia by 89% (2.30 Mb/d to 0.26 Mb/d) from 2021 to 2024. The Americas and Africa significantly offset this decline: U.S. imports surged 88% (0.75 Mb/d to 1.40 Mb/d), Brazil 157% (0.18 Mb/d to 0.45 Mb/d), Guyana 1626% (0.02 Mb/d to 0.33 Mb/d), and Angola 403% (0.04 Mb/d to 0.18 Mb/d). Norwayâ€™s exports grew 36% (0.81 Mb/d to 1.10 Mb/d), Saudi Arabia 40% (0.47 Mb/d to 0.66 Mb/d), and Kazakhstan 48% (0.68 Mb/d to 1.00 Mb/d). This shift underscores a profound reconfiguration of EU oil supply chains.

6 years ago i was working at a gas station making $70 a day

Every day the same shit

Fill tanks, stock shelves, and wash windows for tips.

Now i trade fulltime and make more in a day than i used to in a month

Here are the 6 things that changed everything for me:

1-Stop looking for the "holy grail" strategy
99% of strategies work if YOU can follow them

2- I wasted 2 years strategy hopping before i realized this
Trade ONE setup on ONE timeframe

Master it completely before you add anything else

3-Be a risk manager FIRST, trader second
I blew 7 accounts thinking i was smarter than i was.

Soon as i started treating myself as the risk department, everything changed

No trade happens without mapping out risk first.

4- Trading is boring when done right

If you're feeling an adrenaline rush, you're gambling not trading

My most profitable days are when i take 2-3 trades MAX

5- Keep a trading journal
Review it weekly and be brutally honest with yourself

All my breakthroughs came from seeing my own patterns

6- You need to be uncomfortable

Comfort breeds laziness

Working 2 jobs, going to college, and trading was probably the best decision I could have made.

Most will read this, then do absolutely nothing different tomorrow

The ones who actually implement will be the ones posting their success stories next year

Nigeria Customs Service Pledges Support for Renewable Energy Trade

â€¦Marks One Year of Advance Ruling Implementation

The Nigeria Customs Service (NCS) has reaffirmed its commitment to promoting seamless and sustainable trade operations, with a renewed focus on facilitating the importation of renewable energy technologies.

The Comptroller-General of Customs (CGC), Adewale Adeniyi, who was represented by Deputy Comptroller-General of Customs (DCG) Caroline Niagwan, in charge of the Tariff and Trade Department, made the pledge in Lagos on Monday, 19 May 2025, during the 2025 edition of the NCS Trade Facilitation Stakeholder Consultative Forum, which also commemorated one year anniversary of the Advance Ruling Programme.

Held under the theme â€œTrade Facilitation Measures for Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency Technologies,â€ the forum brought together key industry stakeholders, development partners, and government officials to explore Customsâ€™ evolving role in supporting Nigeriaâ€™s transition to a low-carbon economy.

Delivering the keynote address, DCG Caroline Niagwan described trade facilitation as central to Customsâ€™ contribution to national development and global sustainability efforts.

â€œWith the increasing volume of global trade, it has become imperative for Customs administrations to adopt mechanisms that support the seamless flow of legitimate trade. Such mechanisms are essential not only for sustaining international commerce but also for enabling small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to benefit from cross-border trade,â€ said DCG Niagwan.

She highlighted key initiatives introduced by the NCS to simplify and modernise Customs operations, including the Unified Customs Management System (UCMS), codenamed Bâ€™Odogwu, the Advance Ruling System, and the Authorised Economic Operator (AEO) Programme.

On Nigeriaâ€™s environmental obligations, the DCG reiterated the NCSâ€™s support for the Green Customs Initiative and multilateral environmental agreements such as the Montreal Protocol and the Paris Agreement.

â€œThe Nigeria Customs Service plays a pivotal role in supporting these national objectives by facilitating the importation of renewable energy technologies and implementing fiscal measures that promote a shift away from fossil fuels, with the ultimate goal of achieving net-zero emissions by 2060,â€ she stated.

As part of the Advance Ruling Programme anniversary celebration, the DCG reaffirmed the Serviceâ€™s commitment to fostering efficient, secure, and sustainable trade operations.

A key highlight of the event was the official launch of the Handbook on Import and Export Procedures for Renewable Energy and Energy-Efficient Technologies, which aims to provide guidance to stakeholders and traders on Customs processes applicable to clean energy equipment.

In a goodwill message, Markus Wagner, Country Director for Nigeria and ECOWAS at GIZ, represented by Duke Benjamin, commended the NCS for its strategic foresight. He remarked that the initiative underscores the critical role of Customs in advancing Nigeriaâ€™s renewable energy aspirations. â€œTodayâ€™s launch represents another significant step towards improving the ease of doing business in Nigeria,â€ he added.

Stakeholders present at the forum also shared testimonials on the positive impact of the Advance Ruling Programme, applauding the NCS for its innovation and responsiveness to the trading community's needs.

The strategy that Brad is calling for (Tesla to trade in it's own stock) is not only (extremely) risky from an investment perspective, it is (extremely) risky - foolhardingly so - from a legal perspective. 
To understand the legal jeopardy Tesla would face, here is Grok's very clear conclusion in it's analysis of the strategy:
"Conclusion:
A Nasdaq-listed company can legally repurchase its shares under strict conditions (Rule 10b-18) and sell shares if compliant with registration and antifraud rules. However, actively trading its own stock to exploit dips and highs risks violating insider trading and market manipulation laws, especially if MNPI is involved or the activity misleads investors. Legal counsel and adherence to SEC regulations are critical to avoid liability."
If you are interested in the detailed analysis, here is the full Grok prompt and response.  https://t.co/iDhYcFK4tl
However, what Grok does NOT analyze is the prospect of a full scale class action suit being brought by aggresive law firms on almost any/every trade conducted by the company (even those, and especially those, that make profits!) There is a reason that companies stick to buying their own shares strictly under the SEC Rule 10b-18 share buy back safe harbor, and almost never because they wish to "buy the dip". That form of trading almost automatically implies MNPI, even when none is involved! This is why Directors and Senior Managers try to only buy or sell shares according to a published plan under safe harbor rules. 
This is a really bad idea: the only consolation is that it would NEVER be approved by the Legal Counsel or the Board of Directors.

#OOTT

<My personal thoughts on natural gas>

It's true that LNG feed gas has been weak recently due to short-term maintenance, but that doesn't matter and won't last long.

The key is the year-end LNG ramp up. US LNG exports, which have already been on the rise for several years, will once again significantly increase towards the end of the year.

During this injection season, traders are bound to have an upside bias and will need to build much more stocks than normal. 

This is because everyone is anticipating the structural demand drivers, leaving the market extremely vulnerable to winter weather variability.

We don't need 5-year avg stocks, we need more than that. Nevertheless we are starting the beginning of the cooling demand season with a pretty good weather model.

L48 production remains stagnant. As the US shale basins are being gasified, we are unlikely to see a dramatic decline in Permian associated gas production despite lower oil prices, but we are certain to see slower growth than consensus at the start of the year.

Even in the traditional gas producing plays (Appalachian, Haynesville), we are seeing pretty good discipline. This is a huge opportunity for commodity funds or traders. 

You can buy producer stocks like $AR and $EQT to gain underlying exposure, and then continue to pursue additional gains through upside-biased short-term derivatives trading whenever the opportunity presents itself through the winter of 25/26.

The only weakness of the natural gas bull thesis is that the bullish consensus is held by a majority of industry veterans, which is understandably uncomfortable when it seems so obvious.

But so far, the natural gas market has worked very well.

*I took advantage of the decline in early April to buy a lot of $AR common stock, and as I already mentioned, I'm doing some short-term buy trades on NG futures.

Chinaâ€™s Coal Calculus: Security vs. Sovereignt

1. Geopolitical Fuel Triggers

   - Taiwan and LNG Fears: China coal for several reasons:
     - 45% of its LNG (liquefied natural gas) imports pass through the Malacca Strait, which is patrolled by the U.S.
     - Coal is domestically abundant, with reserves totaling 137 billion tons.
   
   - Nuclear Limitations: Nuclear power contributes only 5% of Chinaâ€™s energy. It is too slow and expensive to significantly replace coal on a large scale before 2035.

2. The Storage Gap

   - China requires over 1,000 GWh of storage capacity for renewables to effectively replace coal, but currently, it has less than 50 GWh.
   - As a result, coal "peakers" are used to back up renewables during periods of low generation, which comes at a substantial costâ€”approximately 1.4 billion tons of COâ‚‚ emissions per year.

3. Renewable Contradiction

   - China is a leader in renewable energy, adding 230 GW in 2023:
     - However, the grid cannot integrate all this renewable energy without coal balancing, which saw an additional 48 GW of coal capacity added in 2023.
   
   - Thus, coal is not replacing renewables; rather, it is facilitating their growth during a challenging transition.
   - For China, coal acts as a "transition" resource, providing vital energy sovereignty amid the looming threats of U.S. sanctions and the ongoing Taiwan conflict.

Nigeria's Cocoa Just Did What Oil Couldn't

Nigeriaâ€™s cocoa exports skyrocketed from N171 billion in 2023 to N2.71 trillion in 2024, a 1,486% jump, fueled by improved processing, mechanized farming, and value-added products.

This surge has revitalized agriculture, boosting forex earnings and creating jobs.

Stock Market Impact

FTN Cocoa Processors Plc, a major player, saw its stock climb from a 200-day average of N1.87 to N2.40, nearing its 52-week high of N2.75, with 1.72 million units traded at N4.18 billion.

Investors are increasingly drawn to agribusiness due to its strong growth potential.

Drivers of the Surge

Government Support: Export Expansion Grants and agro-processing loans enhance competitiveness.

Global Demand: High demand for quality cocoa products in Europe and Asia.

Investor Shift: Portfolios are pivoting to agriculture as a high-potential sector.

Naira Devaluation: Boosts profitability of cocoa exports, serving as a currency hedge.

Enhanced Processing: Upgraded facilities improve efficiency and minimize waste.

Outlook and Challenges

Nigeria could rise to a top global cocoa exporter, driving investment in agro-processing and logistics.

Challenges like infrastructure gaps and climate risks persist, but the sectorâ€™s outlook is robust.

-Tesla v. Zhongjie â€œJayâ€ Li (2025)

Details: Tesla filed a lawsuit against former engineer Alexander Yatskov in May 2022, alleging he stole trade secrets related to its AI-training supercomputer, Dojo, by downloading confidential and proprietary information. The case was settled in April 2023, as reported in a San Francisco federal court filing.

Details: Tesla sued former employee Guangzhi Cao, accusing him of stealing trade secrets related to Autopilot technology and sharing them with his new employer, XMotors (XPeng). More people unsubscribed from our free newsletter than any other day following Wednesday's email.

I sent out a newsletter outlining how we use relative strength to get into winning trades before everyone else.

I used our trade on $CVX from late 2021 as a focal point: 

We bought the strongest sector, in stocks that were showing relative strength, in a market that was beginning to breakdown.

It just so happened that Russia invaded Ukraine in February and our energy stocks shot up in value.

We had no idea that was going to happen. And that was the point.

Someone else did. There was a reason why the market wasn't selling energy stocks. And we caught onto that and followed along and made a bunch of money.

Fast forward to last Friday: 

The same situation. Energy stocks were, out of no where, showing relative strength.

Crude oil was back up and over a key level that made us act and so we did.

We bought $XOM -- and today they're up big.

The news headlines get the praise, but the profits came from a position being opened last Friday. 1 week ago. With no prior knowledge of war.

It was relative strength; the second most important idea in our Profits Over Prophets Framework.

I got replies back from Wedneday night's email along the lines of: 

"How dare you make light of Ukraines situation" or "This is sick. Who cares about your profits?"

I have bad news, folks. 

If you're in the market as a speculator, you have two choices:

- Act on what the market is telling you to make as much money as you possibly can,
- Get mad at everyone else who does it instead.

I'd rather be the winner. It's that simple.

Relative strength matters. And it can make you a lot of money if you're willing to listen.

Anyway, we're long a few energy stocks. We'll see how this summer plays out.

I keep seeing people explaining to me that it doesn't matter if Israel's strikes disrupt Iranian oil exports since only China buys oil from Iran. This is deeply confused, but that confusion seems very widespread, so it's worth explaining why.

The oil market is global, so if you reduce Iranian exports, it will increase prices for everyone and not just China because the Chinese will have to get the oil they're no longer getting from Iran from somewhere else and that will bid prices up.

Of course, that's not the only or even the main reason why the war increases oil prices, the main reason is that, because of the risk of regional spillover, as long as it lasts it creates uncertainty about the reliability of oil supplies and that's reflected in prices.

What are alternatives if Iran closes the straits of Harmouz, Grok?

If Iran were to close the Strait of Hormuz, a critical chokepoint for roughly 20-30% of global oil trade, the primary alternative for oil and gas exports from the Persian Gulf would be limited-capacity pipelines bypassing the strait. Hereâ€™s an overview of the main alternatives and their challenges:
1. Existing Pipelines
Saudi Arabiaâ€™s Petroline (East-West Pipeline):
Capacity: Approximately 5 million barrels per day (bpd).
Route: Connects oil fields in eastern Saudi Arabia to the Red Sea port of Yanbu, bypassing the Strait of Hormuz.
Status: Has spare capacity of about 2 million bpd, but this is insufficient to cover the 17-20 million bpd typically transiting the strait.ğŸ“·
Challenges: Limited spare capacity, vulnerability to regional instability (e.g., Houthi attacks in the Red Sea), and the need for upgrades to handle significantly increased volumes.
Abu Dhabiâ€™s Crude Oil Pipeline:
Capacity: Around 1.5 million bpd.
Route: Transports oil from Abu Dhabiâ€™s oil fields to the port of Fujairah on the Gulf of Oman, bypassing the strait.
Status: Can handle roughly 75% of the UAEâ€™s crude output, but this is a fraction of the regionâ€™s total exports.ğŸ“·
Challenges: Limited capacity and inability to compensate for other Gulf producers like Iraq or Kuwait.

Iraqâ€™s Pipelines:
Capacity: The Iraq-Turkey Pipeline (partially operational) and southern export terminals like Basra have limited bypass potential.
Challenges: Many pipelines are outdated, under repair, or disrupted by geopolitical issues. Iraq relies heavily on the strait for exports.ğŸ“·

Iranâ€™s Jask Terminal:
Capacity: Limited, designed to handle some of Iranâ€™s own exports.
Route: Located in the Gulf of Oman, bypassing the strait.
Status: Operational since 2021 but primarily serves Iranâ€™s needs, not other Gulf producers.ğŸ“·
Challenges: Iranâ€™s own exports would be curtailed by a strait closure, and itâ€™s unlikely to share capacity with rivals.

2. Unused or Underutilized Pipelines

Spare Capacity: The U.S. Energy Information Administration estimates about 2.6 million bpd of unused pipeline capacity from Saudi Arabia and the UAE combined.ğŸ“·
Challenges: This is far below the volume needed to replace strait exports. Many pipelines are old, require maintenance, or face political and security risks (e.g., in Yemen or Syria).

3. Non-Pipeline Alternatives

Overland Transport: Trucking oil or gas is impractical due to the massive volumes involved, high costs, and logistical complexities across conflict-prone regions.

Alternative Sea Routes: There are no viable maritime routes to bypass the Strait of Hormuz, as itâ€™s the only sea passage from the Persian Gulf to the open ocean.ğŸ“·

Increased Production Elsewhere: Countries like the U.S., Russia, or Canada could ramp up production, but this would take months and wouldnâ€™t fully offset the immediate loss of Gulf oil. The U.S., now a major exporter, could mitigate some impact for Western markets.ğŸ“·
Strategic Reserves: Nations like the U.S., China, and members of the International Energy Agency could release strategic petroleum reserves to stabilize markets temporarily, but this is a short-term fix.

4. Economic and Geopolitical Considerations

Impact on Global Markets: A closure would likely spike oil prices by 50% or more, potentially pushing prices above $100 per barrel, causing economic disruption worldwide.ğŸ“·ğŸ“·
Iranâ€™s Own Losses: Closing the strait would cut Iranâ€™s oil exports (1.65 million bpd in 2024), which account for 65% of its government revenue, risking domestic instability.ğŸ“·ğŸ“·

Military Response: The U.S. Fifth Fleet, based in Bahrain, and allied navies could reopen the strait through minesweeping, escorts, or airstrikes, though this risks escalation.ğŸ“·ğŸ“·

China and India: As major importers of Gulf oil, they would pressure Iran to avoid closure, as it would harm their economies more than Western nations.ğŸ“·ğŸ“·

5. Practicality of Closure

Iran has the capability to disrupt the strait using mines, anti-ship missiles, drones, or fast boats, but a sustained closure is unlikely due to international backlash and self-inflicted economic damage.ğŸ“·ğŸ“·
Historical precedent (e.g., the 1980s Tanker War) shows Iran has disrupted shipping but never fully closed the strait.ğŸ“·

Conclusion

The primary alternativesâ€”Saudi and UAE pipelinesâ€”offer limited capacity, covering only a fraction of the 17-20 million bpd transiting the strait. Global oil markets would face severe disruption, with no immediate substitute for Gulf exports. Mitigation would rely on strategic reserves, increased non-Gulf production, and military efforts to reopen the strait, but these are short-term or high-risk options. Iranâ€™s own economic dependence on the strait makes a prolonged closure improbable.

On 10 June, Zimbabwe announced that it would ban exports of lithium concentrates starting in 2027 to retain more profits from its rich mineral deposits through at least two firms with $1 billion in Chinese investment willing to turn raw lithium into battery-grade lithium for electric vehicles and portable devices. 

This move follows a 2022 ban on exports of lithium ore (the raw mined material), part of a broader crusade to benefit Zimbabweâ€™s economy and a trend amongst mineral-rich African states aiming to move beyond raw material exports. 

For example, Namibia halted exports of unprocessed lithium and rare earths in 2023 to drive domestic processing. In 2021, the Democratic Republic of the Congo tightened controls on cobalt and copper concentrates to encourage in-country refining. However, probably the most famous examples include those of the Alliance of Sahel States, comprising Burkina Faso, Mali and Niger. These three countries ousted Western-aligned leaders in recent years and have embarked on a decolonisation process that includes reclaiming natural resources from foreign hands.

Returning to Zimbabwe, the country boasts Africa's largest lithium reserves and is among the world's top lithium producers. 

Back in 2023, Zimbabwean Mines Minister Winston Chitando said that Zimbabwe needed to â€˜move up the value chain.â€™ The government had required producers to submit plans by March 2024 for local processing.

#US calls on #China to prevent #Iran from closing Strait of Hormuz and disrupting global oil flows

U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio on Sunday called for China to prevent Iran from closing the Strait of Hormuz, one of the most important trade routes for crude oil in the world.

"I encourage the Chinese government in Beijing to call them about that, because they heavily depend on the Straits of Hormuz for their oil," Rubio said in an interview on Fox News. China is Iran's most important oil customer and maintains friendly relations with the Islamic Republic.

Iran's foreign minister warned earlier Sunday that the Islamic Republic "reserves all options to defend its sovereignty," after the U.S. bombed three key nuclear sites over the weekend.

Iranian state-owned media, meanwhile, reported that Iran's parliament backed closing the Strait of Hormuz, citing a senior lawmaker. However, the final decision to close the strait lies with Iran's national security council, according to the report.

An attempt to block the narrow waterway between Iran and Oman could have profound consequences for the global economy. Some 20 million barrels per day of crude oil, or 20% of global consumption, flowed through the strait in 2024, according to the Energy Information Administration.

Oil prices could shoot above $100 per barrel if the strait is closed for a prolonged period, according to Goldman Sachs and consulting firm Rapidan Energy. JPMorgan analysts view the risk of Iran closing Hormuz as low because the U.S. would view such a move as a declaration of war.

Rubio said it would be "economic suicide" for Iran to close the strait because the Islamic Republic's oil also passes through the waterway. Iran is the third-largest oil producer in OPEC, pumping 3.3 million barrels per day. It exports at least 1.6 million bpd, with nearly 80% sold to China, according to the EIA.

Closure of the Strait of Hormuz & the impact on the price of farm produce in Nigeria.

Surge in Oil and Fuel Prices: The Strait of Hormuz handles about 20% of global oil and 20% of LNG trade. A closure could push Brent crude oil prices to $120-$150 per barrel, or even $350 in extreme scenarios. Nigeria, despite being an oil producer, relies heavily on imported refined petroleum products due to limited domestic refining capacity. A spike in global oil prices would increase the cost of petrol and diesel, potentially reaching N2,000-N3,000 per litre in Nigeria.

Increased Agricultural Input Costs: Nigerian farmers depend on imported inputs like fertilizers, pesticides, and machinery fuel. The Middle East, via the Strait, supplies 16.3% of global seaborne fertilizer trade. A closure would disrupt these supplies, driving up prices.

Food Inflation and Supply Chain Disruptions: Higher fuel and input costs would translate to elevated food prices. Nigeriaâ€™s inflation rate, already high (around 32% in mid-2025), could worsen as transport and production costs due to our Nigeriaâ€™s import-dependent economy. Additionally, Nigeria imports agricultural commodities like wheat and sugar through global trade routes affected by higher shipping costs and insurance premiums, exacerbating food price hikes.

Currency Pressure and Economic Instability: Nigeriaâ€™s reliance on oil exports (over 80% of foreign exchange earnings) means a global price spike could temporarily boost revenue, but a Strait closure would disrupt trade logistics, weakening the naira due to higher import bills. A weaker naira would make imported inputs and food even more expensive, hitting consumers hard. Rural farmers, often operating on thin margins, would struggle to absorb these costs, potentially reducing output and tightening food supply.

Mitigating Factors: Nigeria has strategic petroleum reserves covering 9-10 days of consumption, which could buffer short-term disruptions. Diversified oil imports from Russia, the U.S., and West Africa (e.g., Nigeriaâ€™s 5% crude imports from Africa) could ease some pressure. However, these measures are insufficient for a prolonged closure, and global spare oil capacity (5.7 million bpd, mostly in Saudi Arabia and UAE) is largely Strait-dependent, limiting relief.

Estimated Impact: Based on historical precedents like the 1970s oil shocks, a sustained closure could double or triple transport and input costs, potentially increasing staple food prices (e.g., rice, yam, or tomatoes) by 30-50% within weeks. Poorer households, spending 60-70% of income on food, would face severe hardship

We hope for dialogue sooner than later.

Striat of Hormuz closure will affect oil movement, which will affect food price in Nigeria. Smallholder farmers will be poorer, food prices will go up, and urban dwellers will spend more on food.

For years, China has been buying discounted Iranian oil in bulk, and the U.S. sanctions on Tehran have barely put a dent in that trade, thanks to a shadow supply chain of transshipment and a yuan-denominated payment system that bypasses the U.S. dollar.

Chinese customs have not shown any oil shipped from Iran since July 2022. Ship tracking data from analytics firm Kpler, however, indicated Chinaâ€™s Iranian crude imports have continued to rise since then, nearly doubling to 17.8 million barrels per day (mbd) in 2024 from the 2022 level.

In the first five months of this year, those imports have remained at an elevated level of 6.8 mbd, little changed from the same period in 2024.

China is still the largest consumer of Iranian crude by far. The U.S. Energy Information Administration suggested in a report in May that nearly 90% of Iranâ€™s crude oil and condensate exports continued to flow to China.

Another problem with the CA Budget.  They are now paying for Fire Suppression (about $1 Billion) out of taxes that CA companies pay for climate change (also called Cap & Trade).  We ultimately pay these taxes because they are passed on in higher gas prices, utilities and goods. 

It makes sense to pay for Fire Prevention out of this fund (removing brush, trees, dangerous fuels so that we donâ€™t have catastrophic fires with huge emissions).  But they are only using $200 million to do that important work. 

Paying for Fire Supression (firefighter response) makes no sense because that is responding to catastrophic fires that have already started, not preventing them.  This has usually been a General Fund cost but that is now being moved over to Cap & Trade to balance the budget.  

Itâ€™s even more problematic because when they want to use that money for some new â€œgreenâ€ project like High Speed Rail, the firefighter budget will get cut. 

In sum this is very bad budget planning that leaves us short on wildfire prevention and vulnerable on funding our state firefighters.

ğŸ“¢Iraq ranked first among the 12 OPEC producers in terms of exports to the United States. ğŸ›¢ï¸ğŸ¤‘
Iraq has boosted exports in recent years, including to the United States, as it hasnâ€™t adhered to its supply quota under the OPEC+ agreements.
But in May, Iraq cut its crude oil production by 50,000 barrels per day (bpd) to 3.93 million bpd, compared to its target of 4.049 million bpd, according to theÂ latest OPEC dataÂ from secondary sources.

Iraq is compensating for previous overproduction as it has been one of the main overproducers in the OPEC+ deal for years, alongside Kazakhstan and Russia, non-OPEC members of the OPEC+ pact. 

Iraq ranked first among the 12 OPEC producers in terms of exports to the United States in May. Shipments totaled nearly 7 million barrels of crude, 6.95 million barrels to be precise.

The second-largest OPEC supplier to the U.S. was Nigeria with 6.803 million barrels of crude oil exports, followed by Saudi Arabia with 6.208 million barrels of crude.

Last month, estimates put Iraqâ€™s crude oil exports to the United StatesÂ surging past 5 million barrelsÂ in May, marking Baghdadâ€™s highest monthly volume to U.S. refiners so far this year.

The surge reflects sustained U.S. appetite for heavier Middle Eastern grades, with Iraqi crude averaging between 160,000 bpd and 190,000 bpd in May.

As OPEC+ maintains voluntary output curbs and U.S. shale growth moderates, Iraq has solidified its position among Washingtonâ€™s top five crude suppliers.

Iraqâ€™s export increase also provides critical fiscal relief for Baghdad, with crude sales accounting for roughly 90% of Iraqâ€™s state revenue.

Recent price support near $80 per barrel has further underpinned Iraqâ€™s monthly revenues, helping finance public sector wages and infrastructure projects.

Known as the "Country of White Gold," Uzbekistan, located at the central Asia, has rich resources of gold, cotton, petroleum, and natural gas. China and Uzbekistan share a long history of trade dating back at least 2,000 years to the Ancient Silk Road. With the development of the China-Europe Railway Express, this vital economic lifeline has transported green beans, raisins, and other agricultural products to dining tables across China. Launched in 2024, the China-Kyrgyzstan-Uzbekistan railway has further deepened connectivity across Eurasia and is expected to be completed in the coming years.

In recent years, Uzbekistan has identified tourism as a key strategic industry, implementing a series of 'rapid reforms" aimed at the fundamental transformation of the entire sector. Due to Uzbekistan's visa-free policy to China since 2020, increasing numbers of Chinese tourists are visiting the country, drawn to its more than 7,300 cultural heritage sites.

In January, 2025, Uzbekistan joined BRICS as a partner country. #BRICS2025 #MyBRICSStory #BRICSStory

FACT: Israel and Iran maintained significant covert trade in oil and weapons until the late 1980s, with activity declining but not disappearing entirely into the 1990s.
Oil Trade:
â€¢From the mid-1950s until the 1979 Iranian Revolution, Iran was Israelâ€™s primary oil supplier, providing over 90% of Israelâ€™s oil imports at times. This relationship was highly secretive, with both sides concealing the extent of their cooperation due to regional sensitivities and Arab opposition.
â€¢After the 1979 Revolution, official diplomatic relations ceased, but clandestine oil trade continued into the 1980s. Iranian oil was sold to Israel through covert channels and intermediaries, such as the Swiss trader Marc Rich, and transported via a secret pipeline.
â€¢This covert oil trade persisted throughout the Iranâ€“Iraq War (1980â€“1988), with Israeli arms sales to Iran often being paid for in oil shipments. The arrangement reportedly continued sporadically and unofficially even after the war, though at a reduced scale.
Weapons Trade:
â€¢During the Iranâ€“Iraq War, Israel was a major supplier of arms to Iran, selling an estimated $500 million to $2 billion worth of weapons annually in the early 1980s. These included anti-tank guns, missiles, spare parts for aircraft, and other military equipment.
â€¢Much of this arms trade was facilitated with the tacit approval of the United States, particularly as part of efforts to prevent an Iraqi victory and later as part of the Iranâ€“Contra Affair (1985â€“1986).
â€¢Arms sales continued after the Iranâ€“Iraq War, but became more sporadic and unofficial, with some reports of Israeli arms deals with Iran into the early 1990s

The tropical Main Development Region of the Atlantic is currently warming significantly, and it can be easily seen as to why when looking 850mb wind charts over the last few days. Weaker than average trade winds and vorticity within the intertropical convergence zone in the low-latitudes have allowed for reduced upwelling, and the sea surface temperature anomaly (SSTA) configuration has improved as a result.

With trade winds expected to continue being weaker than average over the next couple of weeks, favorable changes in the background state of the basin are possible with a weaker differential between tropical and subtropical SSTAs being present.

ğŸš¨ Rumors swirl that @POTUS may be preparing a massive move to end Putinâ€™s war by tanking Russiaâ€™s oil revenues â€” maybe as soon as Monday.

Could he do it? Heâ€™s the one person on Earth who might actually pull it off.

ğŸ§µHereâ€™s how:

1. The idea? Crush Russiaâ€™s oil exports, which fund ~40% of the Kremlinâ€™s budget. But thereâ€™s a twist: He hates high oil prices more than any president in history. If he goes through with this, itâ€™s a game of chicken â€” between oil prices and economic war.

2. For context: Russia exports ~7 million barrels/day of oil & petroleum products (of which about 4.5mbpd crude; of that India buys about 1.7mbpd and China about 2.2mbpd). 

Thatâ€™s too much for even OPEC to replace if such sanctions deter Indian & Chinese refiners perfectly for a while. 

Of course, oil markets are never perfect. Instead, oil always finds a way. Sellers and buyers meet â€” sanctions or not. 

But that is ONLY true over time. In the short term, sanctions force all actors to reconsider their positions and thus absolutely create a supply shock to the market if introduced on a tight timeline.

3. Today, India and China buy some 70% of Russian crude, mostly at a discount. This isnâ€™t a loophole â€” itâ€™s by design. Western sanctions aim to limit Russiaâ€™s income while keeping prices manageable for the West. That is also why the West (US & Europe) introduced the sanctions gradually over 12-15 months in 2022. It gave everyone the time to rearrange themselves. 

But Trumpâ€™s approach may flip that script. He could introduce a tariff shock with immediate effect to which oil prices will react because â€” for the very least â€” the shorts are forced to cover their positions. 

4. The proposed Sanctioning Russia Act of 2025 targets countries helping fund Russiaâ€™s war by continuing to import Russian energy.

It proposes a 500% tariff (!!) on imports by the United States from countries (like India & China) that buy Russian oil.

5. Thatâ€™s a big stick. And Trump could wield it effectively â€” if heâ€™s willing to stomach the oil price shock that might follow for a limited period.

6. The bill also includes an escape hatch, giving Trump max leverage to negotiate peace with the Kremlin: The president can issue a 180-day waiver to any country based on U.S. national security interests. 

A second waiver may be possible under certain conditions (per Hill reporting). This gives flexibility â€” and leverage.

â¸»

Bottom line: If Trump backs this fully, it could mark the most aggressive energy sanctions in modern history. Big oil, geopolitics, tariffs, and a high-stakes showdown with Putin and oil markets â€” all in one.

RECORD SOYBEAN EXPORTS IN FIRST HALF OF 2025

Argentina's soybean exports hit a historic high in the first half of 2025, with 31.1 million tons registered, comprising 61% subproducts, 24% beans, and 14% oil, according to the Rosario Stock Exchange.

This surge, driven by a temporary reduction in export taxes, also led to a record $16 billion in US dollars.

Viterra led soybean complex sales, excelling in oil and subproducts with 1.1 and 4.2 million tons, respectively, while ADM Agro topped bean exports with 1.1 million tons.

Overall, Cargill led grain exports with 9.6 million tons, followed by Viterra and Cofco, highlighting Argentina's robust agro-export sector.

Source: Argentine Central Bank and @SalvadorVitell1
