Middle East Eye published a report titled â€œFrom Sudan to Ukraine: Why Colombian mercenaries keep fighting foreign warsâ€ by journalist IÃ±igo Alexander, exposing the central role of the United Arab Emirates (UAE) in recruiting and financing Colombian mercenaries to fight alongside the Rapid Support Militia (Janjaweed) against the Sudanese Armed Forces.

According to the report, Sudanese military authorities submitted a formal letter to the UN Security Council stating that they had collected â€œextensive evidenceâ€ of â€œa systematic campaign by the UAE to undermine peace, security, and the sovereignty of Sudan, through the recruitment, financing, and deployment of mercenaries fighting alongside the Rapid Support Militia (Janjaweed).â€ While Khartoum presented these findings, Abu Dhabi flatly denied the allegations.

The recruitment process, as the investigation reveals, was orchestrated through a Colombian private security firm contracted by an Emirati company called Global Security Services Group. These mercenaries were deployed to fight within a battalion known as the â€œDesert Wolves,â€ commanded by a retired Colombian general based in Dubai â€” evidence that the operational hub of this network is managed from within the UAE itself.

The routes used to move the mercenaries to Sudan were not improvised but carefully structured. Initially, mercenaries traveled from Abu Dhabi to Benghazi in Libya, where their passports were confiscated to prevent them from returning home. As this pathway became widely known, the UAE facilitated alternative routes through Madrid, Ethiopia, and the Somali port city of Bosaso, then onward to Nâ€™Djamena in Chad, before finally arriving in Nyala, a city under Janjaweed control in Darfur.

Professor Sean McFate of the U.S. National Defense University noted that Colombians are considered â€œexcellent fighters with a lot of combat experience and strong discipline,â€ and at the same time â€œcost a quarter of what an American mercenary would cost.â€ He added: â€œThe UAE is a huge consumer of mercenary services. They have the money, they have the geopolitical ambitions to dominate the Middle East and parts of North Africa. There is demand from the Janjaweed, money from the UAE, and supply from Colombia.â€

The report concludes that the UAE is not merely a secondary supporter but an active player fueling Sudanâ€™s war through its vast oil wealth, turning former Colombian soldiers into a cheap commodity in the marketplace of conflict. This role not only escalates Sudanâ€™s suffering but also undermines prospects for peace and shields perpetrators from accountability, as the use of mercenaries allows state actors like Abu Dhabi to wage proxy wars behind a cloak of plausible deniability.

ğŸ”¥Boom! KRG, Baghdad, Oil Firms Sign Deal to Resume Kurdistan Oil ExportsğŸ’¥

ERBIL â€“ The Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG), Iraqâ€™s Ministry of Oil, and oil-producing companies have signed a trilateral agreement to resume oil exports from the Kurdistan Region, BasNews has learned.

The agreement, signed Monday afternoon in Erbil, clears the way for the re-export of Kurdish crude through Turkeyâ€™s Ceyhan port after more than two years of suspension. 

The deal is expected to be formally announced by Prime Minister Mohammed Shia al-Sudani at Tuesdayâ€™s Iraqi Council of Ministers meeting, where further details will be released.

Earlier in the day, a technical delegation from Iraqâ€™s state-run North Oil Company visited Erbil to finalize export procedures. The delegation held a four-hour meeting with the KRGâ€™s Ministry of Natural Resources, paving the way for the dealâ€™s conclusion.

Under the agreement, the Kurdistan Region will hand over 230,000 barrels of crude per day to the State Organization for Marketing of Oil (SOMO), while retaining 50,000 barrels for domestic consumption. Exports will flow to Ceyhan via the North Oil Company.

KRG spokesperson Peshawa Hawramani had told BasNews on Monday that such a deal was imminent, stressing that it would remove obstacles to the transfer of federal salaries to Kurdistan Region employees.

Oil exports from the Kurdistan Region through Ceyhan were halted in March 2023 following a ruling by the International Chamber of Commerceâ€™s Court of Arbitration in Paris.

The court found that Turkey had violated a 1973 pipeline agreement by allowing Erbil to independently export crude without Baghdadâ€™s consent between 2014 and 2018, ordering Ankara to pay $1.5 billion in damages to Iraq.

Although Turkey has appealed the ruling, it has signaled readiness to reopen the pipeline once Baghdad and Erbil reach an internal settlement. The suspension has cost the KRG billions of dollars in revenue and deepened its reliance on federal budget transfers to cover public sector salaries.

The resumption of exports is seen as a breakthrough for both Erbil and Baghdad, potentially easing long-standing disputes over oil and revenue sharing while reassuring international oil companies invested in the Kurdistan Region.

The process of exporting oil from the Kurdistan Region is nearing its conclusion, with expectations that the export operations will officially resume within the next two days.

Delegations from Kurdistan and Oil Companies to Visit Baghdad Tomorrow

A delegation from the Kurdistan Regional Governmentâ€™s Ministry of Natural Resources, along with representatives from oil companies, will visit Baghdad tomorrow. The purpose of this visit is to finalize the agreement regarding the resumption of oil exports from the Kurdistan Region with the Iraqi government and Iraqâ€™s Ministry of Oil.

Tripartite Meeting to Resolve Outstanding Issues

A tripartite meeting has been scheduled between the Kurdistan Regional Governmentâ€™s Ministry of Natural Resources, oil companies, and Iraqâ€™s Ministry of Oil. This meeting will take place at the headquarters of Iraqâ€™s Ministry of Oil in Baghdad. The Sources indicate that during this meeting, the parties will address and resolve the remaining obstacles and concerns related to restarting oil exports from the Kurdistan Region. If any further issues arise, they will be discussed and unified during this session. This meeting is intended to reach a settlement and will yield concrete results.

Exports to Resume via SOMO and Ceyhan Port

According to the same sources, the agreement between Iraqâ€™s Ministry of Oil, the Kurdistan Region, and the oil companies will be finalized during tomorrowâ€™s meeting. The report emphasizes that following the ratification of the agreement, oil exports from the Kurdistan Region will resume on Tuesday, September 23, 2025, through the Ceyhan port in Turkey, under the supervision of Iraqâ€™s State Organization for Marketing of Oil (SOMO).

Production and Distribution Details

Currently, the Kurdistan Region produces approximately 233,000 barrels of oil per day from its fields. Under the terms of the agreement, 50,000 barrels per day will be allocated for domestic consumption within the Kurdistan Region, while the remaining volume will be handed over to SOMO for export. In accordance with Iraqâ€™s budget law, the Ministry of Oil is obligated to cover the costs of production and transportation, paying $16 per barrel to the oil-producing companies operating in Kurdistan.

Bloomberg: Representatives of the Indian government have once again informed the administration of President Donald Trump that the significant decrease in crude oil purchases by Indian refineries in South Asia from Russia requires the United States to grant permission to acquire energy resources from sanctioned suppliers such as Iran and the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela.

This information was also confirmed by other sources familiar with the negotiations.

KRG Announces Landmark Agreement to Resume Oil Exports Starting 6:00 AM, Saturday, September 27, 2025

The Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG) expressed its satisfaction with reaching a trilateral agreement to resume oil exports from the Kurdistan Region. The government emphasized that this step could strengthen financial stability and help resolve the salary crisis affecting public employees in the region.

Summary of the Agreement

The agreement consists of six main and preliminary articles and was formally signed by Iraqâ€™s Ministry of Oil, the KRGâ€™s Ministry of Natural Resources, and participating oil companies. It clearly outlines the rights, obligations, and commitments of all three parties involved.

Resumption of Oil Exports

It has been decided that at exactly 6:00 AM on Saturday, September 27, 2025, oil from the Kurdistan Region will once again flow through the Kurdistanâ€“Ceyhan pipeline to international markets.

Financial and Marketing Mechanism

Under the new agreement, Iraqâ€™s State Oil Marketing Organization (SOMO) will take responsibility for marketing Kurdistanâ€™s oil. The revenue from oil sales will be transferred to the federal treasury in Baghdad. Simultaneously, non-oil revenues from the Kurdistan Region will also be deposited into the federal treasury. This arrangement ensures that the Kurdistan Region contributes to Iraqâ€™s overall revenue growth.

KRG: Ending the Salary Crisis

According to the KRGâ€™s official statement, the primary goal of this agreement is to resolve the salary crisis and ensure financial fairness for the Kurdistan Region. The government expressed hope that the deal would lead to consistent salary payments and end the uncertainty faced by public employees. It stressed the importance of separating salary issues from political disputes. Revenues will be allocated within the framework of Iraqâ€™s national budget to cover the Regionâ€™s salary and financial entitlements.

Revealing its role, Washington: The Baghdad-Kurdistan agreement will enhance regional energy security

US Secretary of State Mike Rubio revealed on Thursday Washington's role in the Baghdad-Kurdistan Region agreement to resume oil exports, stressing that it will enhance "regional security."

"We welcome the announcement that the Government of Iraq has reached an agreement with the Kurdistan Regional Government and international companies to reopen the Iraq-Turkey pipeline, an agreement facilitated by the United States that will deliver tangible benefits to Americans and Iraqis alike," Rubio said in a press statement.

He added, "We commend the decisive efforts of Iraqi Prime Minister Mohammed Shia al-Sudani and senior Iraqi government officials, as well as Kurdistan Regional Government Prime Minister Masrour Barzani and senior KRG officials, to achieve this progress."

He continued, "This agreement will strengthen the mutually beneficial economic partnership between the United States and Iraq, encourage a more stable investment environment across Iraq for American companies, enhance regional energy security, and strengthen Iraqi sovereignty."

Iraqi Prime Minister Mohammed Shia al-Sudani announced Thursday evening that he had reached an oil agreement with the Kurdistan Region, describing it as "historic." The federal Ministry of Oil indicated that the agreement is the result of ongoing efforts over the past months to establish clear mechanisms to ensure smooth export flows and transparency in revenues .

It's worth noting that the Kurdistan Regional Government's Ministry of Natural Resources, the Iraqi Ministry of Oil, and oil companies signed a tripartite agreement last Monday, paving the way for the resumption of the export of Kurdistan Region oil via the Ceyhan pipeline.

Kurdistan Region oil exports were halted on March 25, 2023, following an international arbitration ruling requiring Turkey not to allow the region's oil exports without the approval of the federal government in Baghdad .

Since then, shipments of an estimated 450,000 barrels per day have been disrupted, including 400,000 from the Kurdistan Region and 50,000 from the northern Kirkuk fields. This disruption has resulted in daily financial losses exceeding $30 million, according to unofficial estimates.

Help me congratulate Dr. Phoutvichay LINSOMPHOU on the successful completion of his PhD under my supervision. His dissertation examines how infrastructure connectivity, trade integration, and renewable energy development shape economic growth in ASEAN countries, filling a major gap in the tradeâ€“growth literature. Unlike studies that focus narrowly on trade volume or rely on growth models with assumptions ill-suited for low-income economies, his research highlights the importance of aligning factor-intensive trade with connectivity modes. Using a dual frameworkâ€”a modified Jones (1996) semi-endogenous model and an augmented Solow modelâ€”it shows that growth in ASEAN depends not on openness alone but on the interaction of trade, infrastructure, and renewable energy. The findings are especially striking for countries like Lao PDR, where renewable energy intensity and human capital amplify the growth effects of capital-intensive trade when supported by efficient transport systems. As a supervisor, it is deeply rewarding to witness such scholarly achievement, which also reminds me with gratitude of the guidance once given by my own PhD mentor.

The muscle of the robots comes from raw materials giving robots strength.

This is often overlooked and consists of metals, magnets, and batteries providing power and motion to robots. 

Think about how smooth a robot has to be to do precision surgery on a human being. That is because of magnets. 

These come from rare earth elements that must be mined and are currently scarce because of how long mines can take to create. You need lightweight neodymium-iron-boron (NdFeB) magnets for robots.

With demand surging for robots, you need about 2 - 4 pounds of rare-earth magnets per humanoid and the scale is expected to be able to produce billions of robots by 2050.

You need supply chain security and China is dominating this space right now. US firms are building domestic capabilities, but a huge risk to the US and advancement is the fact that China is dominating this right now.

Demand has soared for rare earth materials, owning companies like $MP is important for your portfolio because the materials will get cheaper and cheaper to produce, but demand is skyrocketing allowing unlimited inflation in the cost to buy those materials.

One big challenge to overcome, beyond cost, is that batteries may only last 2-4 hours per charge. There needs to be more innovation here to overcome this limitation.

The $TSLA breakout is a good lesson in what to look for if you want to swing big.

Letâ€™s start with the technicals of this trade.

We see that the stock suffered a major decline, bottomed in April around $220, pushed to $350, then spent over four months consolidating between $300 and $350. This is a textbook pattern, a big decline, big advance off a low, followed by a long consolidation.

This allowed all key moving averages to tighten on the daily and weekly timeframe.

The most important technical aspect of this trade is the volatility contraction. May to September volatility slowly decreased and price action tightened. If you start in May, the pullbacks got less severe as the base progressed. 

From the peak in May to the breakout in September, the declines were: -26%, -20%, -13%, -10%, -9%.

This is textbook, less sellers continued to show up as the base progressed. From contraction comes expansion.

The narrative and fundamental aspect of the trade is what juiced it further.

Tesla has bet its entire future on AI. While other big tech names only had AI as part of their business, Tesla was betting the company on it. The AI trade is progressing, people are looking for who can actually apply AI to physical products. Robotics and autonomous driving are the pinnacle of AI and Tesla was already seen as the face of both. The Robotaxi app wide release also came just days before the breakout.

The macro backdrop had turned supportive. Rate cut talk picked up after Jackson Hole and lower borrowing costs means easier car financing for consumers and more enterprise investment into Tesla energy.

Earnings have been poor which means earnings comps going forward are extremely low after many weak quarters. That sets the stage for even EPS and revenue growth to flip the narrative. The market is forward looking.

There is also a major shift in sentiment around Elon. Heâ€™s stepped back from politics and referred to it as a side quest in his past. That showed his commitment to Tesla which had been in question for over a year.

The biggest piece was his new compensation package which tied his $ directly to autonomy, robotics, and FSD adoption. The milestones are astronomical which aligned his incentives with shareholders.

If you missed this trade donâ€™t sweat it, just know these opportunities present themselves over and over again so try and be ready next time. The best trades have much more than a nice chart, all of the stars aligned.

Pennsylvania: In PJM (~20% coal, 7% renewables), clean coal boosts exports and stability. (See the Note at the bottom of this post for PJM's unique coal generation benefits)

Wyoming:
Coal powers 80% of the grid, with wind/solar at 15%. Clean coal replaces retiring plants, ensuring steady baseload in the Western Interconnection.

West Virginia: In PJM (~20% coal, 7% renewables), clean coal sustains reliability and jobs.

Illinois: MISO grid, 25% wind, 5% solar. Clean coal anchors baseload for consistent power.

Montana: Western Interconnection, 15% renewables. Clean coal enhances exports and reliability.

By replacing aging plants, down from 310 GW in 2010 to 180 GW in 2023, clean coal complements renewables for a strong grid, cost effective grid, a prerequisite to any industrial revival in our heartland.

- Clean coal boosts supply, curbing rate hikes (ğŸ“‰ vs. 22% spike for 2026).

1. Venezuelaâ€™s Oil Wealth

Venezuela has the largest proven oil reserves in the world, even more than Saudi Arabia.

Oil makes up about 95% of Venezuelaâ€™s exports and is the backbone of its economy.

2. U.S. Sanctions & Economic Collapse

In the 2010s, the U.S. imposed heavy sanctions on Venezuelaâ€™s oil industry (especially on state oil company PDVSA).

These sanctions were meant to pressure NicolÃ¡s Maduroâ€™s government.

The result: Venezuela was cut off from the U.S. financial system, couldnâ€™t sell oil freely, and its currency collapsed.

This triggered hyperinflation, with basic goods costing millions of bolÃ­vars.

3. China Steps In

While the U.S. tried to choke Venezuela economically, China and Russia stepped in as lifelines.

China has loan-for-oil deals with Venezuela, meaning Venezuela sends crude in exchange for Chinese financing.

In recent years, China buys much of Venezuelaâ€™s sanctioned oil at a discount, rerouting it through middlemen or blending it to hide its origin.

4. Why the U.S. Wants It

The U.S. still wants access to Venezuelan oil because:

Itâ€™s close geographically (cheap transport compared to Middle East).

It could help stabilize oil prices and reduce dependence on OPEC and hostile states.

American refineries are built to process Venezuelaâ€™s heavy crude.

5. The Big Picture

Venezuelaâ€™s crisis wasnâ€™t just from â€œbad socialismâ€ or â€œmismanagementâ€ â€” U.S. sanctions crushed its ability to sell oil legally.

China filled the gap, securing cheap energy while building political influence in Latin America.

Now the U.S. is reconsidering its stance, since blocking Venezuela only pushed it deeper into Chinaâ€™s orbit.
